[[File:festivallatinoamericano.jpg|thumb|View of Festival Vendors]] '''Festival Latinoamericano''', or ''Latin American Festival'', is an annual three-day [[Labor Day]] weekend festival in downtown [[Provo, Utah]]. The festival highlights [[Utah]]'s Hispanic culture through food, vendors, and performances and is free to the public. [[Centro Hispano]] hosts Festival Latinoamericano. It is currently in its fourteenth year.
==History and Purpose== During the first year in 2001, the Festival was held at the Boulders Apartment Complex with about 75 attendants. The inaugural festival was a giant success, and quickly outgrew its South Provo location. The festival has since become a large yearly event in downtown Provo on the Utah County Historic Courthouse grounds on University Avenue and Center Street. In the last six years the festival has maintained an attendance of approximately 30,000 visitors.<ref>http://www.centrohispanouc.org/FestivalLatinoamericano/tabid/197/language/en-US/Default.aspx Festival Background</ref>
The Festival's purpose is to provide a venue for nonprofit organizations and new companies to provide their services to the Hispanic population. The audience at this event is not restricted to the state of Utah; there are visitors from multiple states including California, Wyoming, and Nevada.
The event showcases local performers of Latin dance and music, and also allows attendees to further explore Latin-American cuisine and culture through dozens of various vendors. Other attractions include carnival rides and [[lucha libre]].
==See also== * [[List of festivals in the United States]] * [[Provo, Utah]] * [[Centro Hispano]]
==External links== *[http://festivalprovo.com/Default.aspx/ Official Site of Festival Latinoamericano] *[http://www.centrohispanouc.org/Default.aspx/ Official Site of Centro Hispano]
==Notes== {{Reflist|1}}
{{Provo, Utah}} {{Coord|40|14|01|N|111|39|31|W|format=dms|display=title|type:event_region:US-UT}}
[[Category:Festivals in Utah]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American culture in Utah]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Provo, Utah]] [[Category:Cultural festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Utah]] [[Category:Latin American festivals]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Organizations|date=December 2009}} {{unreferenced|date=December 2009}} }}
'''Festival Welfare Services''' is a United Kingdom [[voluntary organisation]] established in 1972 to improve [[Public welfare|welfare service]]s at [[pop festival]]s. Prior to formation of FWS a variety of voluntary groups were providing services at festivals which, at the instigation of [[Release (agency)|Release]], came together to improve their cooperation and effectiveness. Following the [[Windsor Free Festival|Windsor]] and [[Watchfield#Watchfield Festival 1975|Watchfield]] festivals the government provided funding, from 1976, for a full-time worker (Penny Mellor) to coordinate FWS activities, although the majority of work remained voluntary. Volunteers often came from a festival-sympathetic background and thus were quite relaxed with even some of the wilder events but also sometimes distrusted by the authorities. Government funding was withdrawn in 1995.
==Publications== * Healthy festival sites: environmental health guidelines for open-air festivals - John Stollery, Festival Welfare Services - 1980 * Community festivals handbook - John Hoyland, Community Projects Foundation, Festival Welfare Services - Social Science - 1983 - 84 pages * Festivals: a survival guide - Festival Welfare Services - Festivals - 1987 - 12 pages * Festivals: safer drug use : a users guide - Trevor McCarthy, Festival Welfare Services - Youth - 1989 - 4 pages * website: [http://www.festivalwelfareservices.co.uk Festival Welfare Services]
==Bibliography== * Clarke, Michael - The Politics of Pop Festivals - 1982
==External links== * [http://www.festivalwelfareservices.co.uk festival welfare services website] * [http://www.ukrockfestivals.com/festival-welfare-service.html Penny Mellor's early experiences with FWS] * [http://www.ukrockfestivals.com/fws-henge1-77-report.html FWS report on 1977] [[Stonehenge Free Festival]] * [http://www.ukrockfestivals.com/glasto77-fws-report.html FWS report on 7-7-77 Glastonbury Free Festival: Street, Somerset]
[[Category:Welfare and service organizations]] [[Category:Free festivals]] [[Category:Counterculture festivals activists]] [[Category:1974 in England]] [[Category:Counterculture]]

The '''Fiesta del Pacifico''' (English: ''Festival of the Pacific'') was a civic [[festival]] held in [[San Diego]], [[California]] during the 1950s. The event was staged throughout the city for several weeks in the mid to late summer. It was intended to attract tourists and to highlight San Diego's [[New Spain|Spanish]] and [[Mexico|Mexican]] heritage.
==History== In 1955 the [[San Diego City Council]] approved a plan for a month-long celebration to take place in the summer of 1956.<ref name = "Golden" /> A private organization run by Wayne Dailard, who had served as manager of the 1936–37 [[California Pacific International Exposition]], put on a 33-day-long event in 1956, with some financial support from the city and [[San Diego County|county]].<ref name="Pourade">{{cite book|last=Pourade|first=Richard F. |title=City of the Dream 1940–1970|url=http://www.sandiegohistory.org/books/pourade/dream/dreamchapter5.htm|year=1977|publisher=Copley Press|chapter=5: A Fiesta – Reliving the days of the dons|ISBN=978-0913938195}}</ref> The fiesta was intended to be an annual event, but revenue projections fell short, and tourism industry representatives complained that it was drawing traffic away from the more established attractions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balboaparkhistory.net/glimpses/expohost.htm|title=Can San Diego hold a legitimate international exposition?|last=Amero|first=Richard W.|date=November 1999|pages=balboaparkhistory.net|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> The festival continued for three more years but was shorter and less ambitious each year: July 18 to August 12 in 1956, July 24 to August 10 in 1957, August 29 to September 9 in 1958, and September 4 to 17 in 1959.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Fiesta-Pacifico-Official-Program-August/dp/B004O4M2LS|title=Fiesta del Pacifico San Diego Official Program July 18 Thru August 12, 1956|work=Fiesta|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref><ref name = "1957 program" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalpostercollection.com/travel/tourism/usa/1958-viva-la-fiesta-del-pacifico-san-diego/|title=1958 Viva La Fiesta del Pacifico! San Diego|date=July 1958|work=Holiday|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref><ref name = "timeline">{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegohistory.org/amero/notes-1959.htm|title=Balboa Park History - 1959|last=Amero|first=Richard|work=sandiegohistory.org|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> After 1959 the fiesta was abandoned.<ref name = "Golden" />
==Description== The festival included weeks of varied activities throughout the city, including a beauty pageant, several parades, a series of road races, a rodeo, street parties, and multiple displays of dancing, art, and other cultural activities. The main event was an epic theatrical production entitled ''The California Story,'' which had originally been written for the California Centennial celebration in 1950 and had been presented in the [[Hollywood Bowl]]. The extravaganza was performed in [[Balboa Stadium]] on a stage as long as a city block. It featured 35 scenes and a cast of 1,300 people, including a symphony orchestra and a 150-voice choir.<ref name = "Pourade" /> [[Lucille Norman]] was the star and lead singer in the 1957 production.<ref>"Fiesta Parade, Pageant Set Today," (July 27, 1957), p. 1, [[The San Diego Union]], [[San Diego, CA]]</ref> It was directed by [[Vladimir Rosing]] and conducted by [[Meredith Willson]]; both had filled the same role at the Hollywood Bowl.<ref name = "program">Official Program, ''Fiesta del Pacifico'', San Diego, 1956</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/metro/freeman/20020601-9999_1c1freeman.html|title='Music Man' still leads Broadway's hit parade|last=Freeman|first=Don|date=June 1, 2002|work=San Diego Union Tribune|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> The production dramatized the history of California from the arrival of [[Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo]] in 1540 through the early 20th century.<ref name="Golden">{{cite book|last=Starr|first=Kevin|title=Golden Dreams: California in an Age of Abundance, 1950–1963|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gvFyunCAQbMC&pg=PT84&lpg=PT84&dq=%22Fiesta+del+Pacifico%22+%22San+Diego%22|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-515377-4|page={{page needed|date=June 2014}}}}</ref> It was billed as "the biggest non-movie spectacle ever produced anywhere."<ref name = "1957 program">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Diego-Fiesta-Pacifico-folder-1957/dp/B00EVUAMFS|title=San Diego Fiesta del Pacifico folder 1957|work=Program|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> In 1959, the last year of the fiesta, the ''California Story'' production was replaced by a 2-hour show called ''Stars over Pacific''.<ref name = "timeline" />
==Legacy== The celebration inspired the most popular and most-performed work by composer [[Roger Nixon]]: a piece for symphonic band called ''Fiesta del Pacifico''. It was composed in 1958–59 and first performed in 1960. Nixon explained the name of his composition as follows: "Fiesta del Pacifico is held in San Diego and features a play on the history of the area, a parade, a rodeo, and street dances. It is one of several festivals held annually in various communities in California that celebrate the Old Spanish Days of the State, and I chose its name as representative of the spirit of those occasions."<ref>{{cite book|last=Salzman|first=Timothy (ed.)|title=A Composer's Insight: Thoughts, Analysis and Commentary on Contemporary Masterpieces for Wind Band|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y6lyqCsgVrYC&pg=PA134|year=2006|publisher=Meredith Music Publications|pages=134–5|chapter=Roger Nixon, by William Berz}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:History of San Diego]] [[Category:Festivals in San Diego]] [[Category:Cultural festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Latin American festivals]]

revision.comment: /* Financial intelligence organizations */ * Zentralstelle für Finanztransaktionsuntersuchungen added
revision.text:
{{redirect|FININT|the firm Finint S.r.l.|Western Union}} {{distinguish|Financial intelligence (business)}} {{refimprove|date=January 2013}} '''Financial intelligence''' ('''FININT''') is the gathering of information about the financial affairs of entities of interest, to understand their nature and capabilities, and predict their intentions. Generally the term applies in the context of law enforcement and related activities.
One of the main purposes of financial intelligence is to identify [[financial transaction]]s that may involve [[tax evasion]], [[money laundering]] or some other criminal activity. FININT may also be involved in identifying financing of criminal and terrorist organisations.
Financial intelligence can be broken down into two main areas, collection and analysis. Collection is normally done by a government agency, known as a financial intelligence organisation or Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU). The agency will collect raw transactional information and [[Suspicious activity report]]s (SAR) usually provided by banks and other entities as part of regulatory requirements. Data may be shared with other countries through intergovernmental networks.
Analysis, may consist of scrutinizing a large volume of transactional data using [[data mining]] or data-matching techniques to identify persons potentially engaged in a particular activity. SARs can also be scrutinized and linked with other data to try and identify specific activity.
==Collection== FININT involves scrutinizing a large volume of transactional data, usually provided by banks and other entities as part of regulatory requirements. Alternatively, [[data mining]] or data-matching techniques may be employed to identify persons potentially engaged in a particular activity.
Many industrialized countries have regulatory reporting requirements for its financial organisations.
It may be possible for the FININT organization to obtain access to raw data at a financial organization. From a legal standpoint, this type of collection can be quite complex. For example, the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] obtained access to the [[Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication]] (SWIFT) data streams through the [[Terrorist Finance Tracking Program]], but this violated Belgian privacy law.
Reporting requirements may not affect [[Informal value transfer system]]s (IVTS)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fincen.gov/advis33.pdf |author=United States Department of the Treasury, Financial Crimes Enforcement Network |title=Informal Value Transfer Systems, FinCEN Advisory Issue 33 |date=March 2003 |id=FinCEN-2003-33 |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121142607/http://www.fincen.gov/advis33.pdf |archivedate=November 21, 2008 |df= }}</ref> the use of which may simply be customary in a culture, and of amounts that would not require reporting if in a conventional financial institution. IVTS also can be used for criminal purposes of avoiding oversight.
==Analysis== Examples of financial intelligence analysis could include: * Identifying high-[[risk]] housing tenants on the basis of past rental histories. * Detecting tax payers trying to avoid their fiduciary obligations by moving wealth surreptitiously out of a tax-levying jurisdiction. * Discovering [[tax haven|safe havens]] where criminals park the proceeds of [[crime]]. * Accounting for how a large sum of money handed to a targeted individual disappears * Checking to see if a corrupt individual has had any sudden and unexplained windfalls. * Detecting relationships between [[terrorist]] cells through remittances.
==Financial intelligence organizations== According to the [[Egmont Group of Financial Intelligence Units]], financial intelligence organizations (FIUs) are national centres which collect information on suspicious or unusual financial activity from the financial industry and other entities or professions required to report transactions suspicious of being money laundering or terrorism financing. FIUs are normally not law enforcement agencies; their mission being to process and analyze the information received. If sufficient evidence of unlawful activity is found, the matter is passed to the public prosecution.<ref name=Egmont>{{cite web|title=What is an FIU?|url=http://www.egmontgroup.org/|accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref>
Government organizations may simply receive and process raw financial reports, and forward them, as appropriate, to law enforcement or intelligence agencies, include the multinational Egmont Group of Financial Intelligence Units, and national organizations, including:
* [[Argentina]] – [[Unidad de Inteligencia Financiera]] * [[Australia]] – [[Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre]] (AUSTRAC) * [[Brazil]] – [[Council for Financial Activities Control|COAF]] Conselho de Controle de Atividade Financeira * [[Canada]] – [[Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada]] (FINTRAC) * [[France]] – [[Tracfin]] * [[Germany]] – [[Zentralstelle für Finanztransaktionsuntersuchungen]] * [[India]] – [[Financial Intelligence Unit]] (FIU-IND)<ref>[http://fiuindia.gov.in/index.htm FIUindia.gov.in]</ref> * [[Ireland]] – [[National Economic Crime Bureau|Garda Financial Intelligence Unit]] (GNECB FIU) * [[United Kingdom]] – [[National Crime Agency]] * [[United States]] – [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]] (FinCEN)
== United States examples == The United States has different organizations focused on domestic and international financial activity. The United States has several laws requiring the reporting to the [[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|FinCEN]]. These include the [[Right to Financial Privacy Act]] (RFPA) of 1978, the [[Bank Secrecy Act]] of 1970 (and other names of revisions), and the [[Gramm–Leach–Bliley Act]] of 1999 (GLBA). Some reports also need to go to the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]].
For example, the reports {| class="wikitable" <Caption>Representative Reports required from US financial institutions</caption> |- ! Report and definition ! Authority ! Receiving Agency |- | '''Currency Transaction Report (CTR)'''. Cash transactions in excess of $10,000 during the same business day. The amount over $10,000 can be either from one transaction or a combination of cash transactions. | Bank Secrecy Act | Internal Revenue Service |- | '''Negotiable Instrument Log (NIL)'''. Cash purchases of negotiable instruments (e.g., money orders, cashiers checks, travelers cheques) having a face value of $3,000, or more. | Bank Secrecy Act | Internal Revenue Service |- |'''Suspicious Activity Report (SAR)'''. Any cash transaction where the customer seems to be trying to avoid BSA reporting requirements (e.g., CTR, NIL). A SAR must also be filed if the customer's actions indicate that s/he is laundering money or otherwise violating federal criminal law. The customer must not know that a SAR is being filed. | Bank Secrecy Act | Financial Crimes Enforcement Network |}
Actions that can trigger an SAR being filed include: :#Any kind of insider abuse of a financial institution, involving any amount; :#Federal crimes against, or involving transactions conducted through, a financial institution that the financial institution detects and that involve at least $5,000 if a suspect can be identified, or at least $25,000 regardless of whether a suspect can be identified; :#Transactions of at least $5,000 that the institution knows, suspects, or has reason to suspect involve funds from illegal activities or are structured to attempt to hide those funds; :#Transactions of at least $5,000 that the institution knows, suspects or has reason to suspect are designed to evade any regulations promulgated under the Bankruptcy Secrecy Act; or :#Transactions of at least $5,000 that the institution knows, suspects, or has reason to suspect have no business or apparent lawful purpose or are not the sort in which the particular customer would normally be expected to engage and for which the institution knows of no reasonable explanation after due investigation. The language of the RFPA indicates that a SAR filed under this rule comes from an individual transaction, not a profile of activities that make the transaction stand out.
===International=== International financial activity comes primarily from the Department of the Treasury and the [[Central Intelligence Agency]]. See [[CIA activities in Russia and Europe#Belgium 2006|CIA access]] to the [[Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication]] (SWIFT).
===US domestic FININT=== At the highest level, US domestic FININT, and also some international work, comes under the [[Under Secretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence]], heading the Office of Terrorism and Financial Analysis, including: *[[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]]: tracks domestic transactions *[[Office of Foreign Assets Control]]: focused on foreign assets in the US *Office of Intelligence and Analysis
Information developed by these units, when related to domestic security and especially when state and local law enforcement, is disseminated by the Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) in the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]], under the [[Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis]]. This Office is not restricted to FININT, but handles collection, analysis and fusion of intelligence throughout the entire Department. It disseminates intelligence throughout the Department, to the other members of the [[United States Intelligence Community]], and to affected [[first responder]]s at the state and local level.
Depending on the specific Federal violation, law enforcement investigation may be under agencies including the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], [[United States Secret Service]], or the [[Internal Revenue Service]].
==Terrorist financing scenarios==
===Gems as an untraceable currency and source of income for terrorists=== Following the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] an allegation was made in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' that [[tanzanite]] stones were being used as an untraceable currency and source of income for terrorists. This has not since been firmly established. See [[CIA Activities by Transnational Topic: Crime and Illicit Drug Trade#Conflict diamonds and militant financing|possible examples]].<ref name=Farah2003>{{cite web | title = The Role of Conflict Diamonds and Failed States in the Terrorist Financial Structure | author = Farah, Douglas | publisher = The Watson Institute, Brown University | date = 2003-10-24 | url = http://www.douglasfarah.com/articles/conflict-diamonds.shtml }}</ref>
The custom common in Africa, uncut diamonds tend to be the de facto standard currency of the illicit small arms trade. Diamonds may be easily counted with a uniform valuation per carat to people in places of the world where there are no automated teller machines. An entire briefcase filled with uncut diamonds without the serial numbers found on refined precious metals can be used to make large illicit value transfers. The practice coexists with human trafficking, narcotics, weapons dealing, terrorism, and the evasion of economic sanctions and embargoes.
However, the [[Internal Revenue Service]] has since instituted new [[anti-money laundering]] regulations to control the gem trade.<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small/article/0,,id=154465,00.html "New Requirement for the Precious Metal, Precious Stone, and Jewel Industries"], irs.gov. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213202653/https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small/article/0%2C%2Cid%3D154465%2C00.html |date=December 13, 2007 }}</ref>
===Front-running the market in a terrorist attack=== Another intriguing possibility is that a terrorist might buy stocks which are likely to appreciate in the event of a terrorist attack, such as defense industry stocks, or sell short stocks which are likely to depreciate, such as airlines. This possibility led to many investigations of the financial markets subsequent to the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]].<ref>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/columnists/chi-0109190296sep19,0,3496437.story "Terrorist trade probe widens: Options buying rose in firms that attack affected", by Robert Manor and Melissa Allison, ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', September 19, 2001]</ref>
== European Financial Intelligence Unit Network == The Financial Intelligence Unit Network (FIU.NET) is a decentralized computer network that provides an information exchange between the financial intelligence units of the European Union.<ref name="Van Duynen">{{cite book|author1=Georgios A. Antonopoulos |author2=Marc Groenhuijsen |author3=Jackie Harvey |author4=Tijs Kooijmans |author5=Almir Maljevic |author6=Klaus Von Lampe |title=Usual and Unusual Organising Criminals in Europe and Beyond: Profitable Crimes, from Underworld to Upper World: Liber Amicorum Petrus Van Duyne|year=2011|publisher=Maklu|location=Netherlands |isbn=978-90-466-0429-8 |page=100 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=M7oV39ilah0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> FIU.NET is a decentralized system with no central database where the information is collected. All the connected FIUs have their FIU.NET equipment within their own premises and manage their own information. Through FIU.NET the connected FIUs create bilateral or multilateral cases. Ma<sup>3</sup>tch (autonomous, anonymous, analysis) is a matching tool within FIU.NET. Ma<sup>3</sup>tch makes it possible for FIUs to match names in order to find relevant data that is possessed by other connected FIUs. As the data is anonymized, there is no breaching of privacy and data protection rules.
===Connected FIUs=== FIU.NET is funded by the European Commission and participating FIUs.<ref name="DG HOME">{{cite web|title=Fundings|url=http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/financing/fundings/projects/stories/fiu_net_en.htm|work=European Commission|publisher=European Commission - DG Home Affairs (HOME)|accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref> Currently, the connected EU Member State FIUs are:<ref name="FIU.NET website">{{cite web|title=Parties involved|url=http://www.fiu.net/home/parties-involved|accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref> Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxemburg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Sweden, Slovenia, Slovakia, Spain, and the United Kingdom.
===Governing body=== FIU.NET is governed by a Board of Partners (BoP) formed by connected FIUs that have volunteered for a seat. The Board of Partners is chaired by an independent Director.<ref name="House of Lords">{{cite book|title=Money laundering and the financing of terrorism: 19th report of session 2008-09, Vol. 2: Evidence|year=2009|publisher=UK- Parliament; House of Lords - The Stationery Office|location=United Kingdom|pages=254–255|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_DV2BA5jzksC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=9780108444692}}</ref>
===Project management=== Daily operation of the system is managed by the FIU.NET Bureau, a project bureau of the Dutch Ministry of Security and Justice, which is housed in the [[Europol International]] Headquarters in [[The Hague]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further sources== *{{cite book|author1=Georgios A. Antonopoulos |author2=Marc Groenhuijsen |author3=Jackie Harvey |author4=Tijs Kooijmans |author5=Almir Maljevic |author6=Klaus Von Lampe |title=Usual and Unusual Organising Criminals in Europe and Beyond: Profitable Crimes, from Underworld to Upper World: Liber Amicorum Petrus Van Duyne|year=2011|publisher=Maklu|location=Netherlands|isbn=978-90-466-0429-8|page=100|url=https://books.google.com/?id=M7oV39ilah0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} *{{cite web|title=What is an FIU?|url=http://www.egmontgroup.org/|accessdate=7 July 2013}} *{{cite web|title=Fundings|url=http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/financing/fundings/projects/stories/fiu_net_en.htm|work=European Commission|publisher=European Commission - DG Home Affairs (HOME)|accessdate=7 July 2013}} *{{cite book|title=Money laundering and the financing of terrorism: 19th report of session 2008-09, Vol. 2: Evidence|year=2009|publisher=UK- Parliament; House of Lords - The Stationery Office|location=United Kingdom|pages=254–255|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_DV2BA5jzksC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=9780108444692}} *[http://www.fiu.net/ fiu.net]
{{espionage}} {{Intelligence cycle management}}
[[Category:Commercial crimes]] [[Category:Financial crime prevention]] [[Category:Intelligence gathering disciplines]] [[Category:Terrorism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:The Fine Art Society 9906158113.jpg|thumb|The Fine Art Society, London]] The '''Fine Art Society''' is a gallery in Dundas Street in [[Edinburgh]]'s [[New Town, Edinburgh|New Town]] (originally Bourne Fine Art, established 1978). The [[New Bond Street]], [[London]] gallery closed its doors in August 2018 after being occupied by The Fine Art Society since February 1876, the entrance facade of which was built in 1881 by [[Edward William Godwin]] (1833–1886).
==History== Founded in 1876 by a group of like-minded men led by William Longman of the publishing family, [[Marcus Bourne Huish]] (1843–1904), lawyer, editor, writer and collector, who became the first Managing Director while at the same time editing ''[[The Art Journal]]''; and [[Archibald Stuart-Wortley (politician)|Archibald Stuart-Wortley MP]]. The gallery, first managed by Ernest Brown (later founder of [[Leicester Galleries]]) has for many years largely concentrated on British art and design from 1600 to the present day; with the Edinburgh premises specialising in Scottish art of the same period. The Edinburgh branch of the company is directed by Emily Walsh. The Chairmen were all drawn from the Longman family until the death of Mark Longman in 1972. Since then only Lord Macfarlane of Bearsden KT (until 1998), Sir Angus Grossart (until 2016) and Robin Holland-Martin (current) have held the position. Only seven people have held the position of Managing Director in the past 139 years, the last being Pippa Stockdale.
The Fine Art Society has taken part in key international art fairs over the years, most notably at [[TEFAF]] Maastricht, Masterpiece, London, [[Frieze Masters]], London and at the [[London Original Print Fair]], whose founder and chairman, Gordon Cooke, is also the society's 19th and 20th century prints specialist. The society has also exhibited in art fairs in New York, Miami, Hong Kong, Paris and Dubai.
==Exhibitions== The gallery is also known as the pioneer of the one-man exhibition, most famously that of [[James McNeill Whistler]]'s First Venice Set of etchings in December 1880; the gallery having sent Whistler to [[Venice]] in 1879 in part to enable him to escape from the issues following his libel action against [[John Ruskin]]. The commission was for Whistler to travel to Venice for three months to create a series of twelve etchings. Beguiled by the city, he stayed for fourteen months and completed approximately fifty etchings. Venice also inspired Whistler to make some hundred works in pastel, of which 53 were shown in the Venice Pastels exhibition in 1881. During Whistler's absence in Venice, the gallery showed his antagonist John Ruskin's private Collection of Watercolours by [[J. M. W. Turner]], and ran a subscription to pay for Ruskin's legal costs: a supreme exhibition of political sleight of hand. Other living exhibitors at the London premises included [[Sir John Everett Millais]], [[John Singer Sargent]], [[Burne-Jones]], [[Frank Brangwyn]], [[Walter Richard Sickert]], [[Walter Crane]], [[George Washington Lambert]], [[Henry Charles Brewer]] and [[Joseph Southall]], and more recently [[Leonard Rosoman]], Emma Sargent, [[Emily Young]], [[John Byrne (playwright)|John Byrne]], [[Alexander Stoddart]] and Geoffrey Clarke. Of many memorial exhibitions held, one was for [[Lady Alma Tadema]] in 1910.
A Contemporary gallery was created in 2005, originally managed by Toby Clarke, subsequently by [[Kate Bryan]], and most recently by Lee Cavaliere. Sara Terzi is now the Contemporary art specialist at the gallery. The Contemporary team have embraced the nineteenth and twentieth century heritage of the gallery and increased cross-cultural links, particularly in Asia, Australia and the US. Among the artists shown are [[Chris Levine]], Angela Palmer, [[Annie Kevans]], [http://thefineartsociety.com/artists/35-jacky-tsai/overview/ Jacky Tsai] and [http://thefineartsociety.com/artists/27-bartholomew-beal/overview/ Bartholomew Beal].
In October 2014 The Fine Art Society Contemporary staged the first exhibition to be held at the gallery across all 5 floors, 'What Marcel Duchamp Taught Me.'<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://howtospendit.ft.com/art/65691-what-marcel-duchamp-taught-me|title = What Marcel Duchamp Taught Me|website = How To Spend It|access-date = 2016-03-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/oct/09/marcel-duchamp-exhibition-celebrate-father-conceptual-art|title = Marcel Duchamp: exhibition to celebrate father of conceptual art|last = Brown|first = Mark|date = 2014-10-09|last2 = correspondent|first2 = arts|newspaper = The Guardian|language = en-GB|issn = 0261-3077|access-date = 2016-03-15}}</ref> The exhibition featured artwork by 50 contemporary global artists including [[Peter Blake (artist)|Sir Peter Blake]], [[Cornelia Parker]], [[Gavin Turk]], [[Chris Levine]], [[Conrad Shawcross]], [[Keith Tyson]], [[Michael Craig-Martin]], [[Jonathan Yeo]], [[Joseph Kosuth]], [[Idris Khan]], [[Annie Kevans]] and [[Charming Baker.]] The exhibition curated by [[Kate Bryan]] was one of the most successful in the history of the gallery<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/artists-to-pay-respects-to-marcel-duchamp-in-new-exhibition-9773803.html|title = Artists to pay respects to the revolutionary Marcel Duchamp in new|website = The Independent|language = en-GB|access-date = 2016-03-15}}</ref> and marked 100 years since [[Marcel Duchamp]] created the [[Found object|readymade]].

{{For|the Foo Fighters song|Friend of a Friend (song)}} {{Wiktionary|FOAF}} In [[sociology]], a '''friend of a friend''' is a human contact that exists because of a mutual friend. Person C is a friend of a friend of person A when there is a person B that is a [[friend]] of both A and C. Thus the human relation "friend of a friend" is a compound relation among friends, similar to the [[uncle]] and [[aunt]] relations of [[kinship]]. Though friendship is a [[symmetric relation|reciprocal relation]], the relation of a friend of a friend may not be a friendship, though it holds potential for coalition building and dissemination of information.
==Balance theory== {{Main|Balance theory}} The tendency of a friend of a friend to become a friend was noted by [[Fritz Heider]],<ref>[[Fritz Heider]] (1946) "Attitudes and Cognitive Organization", [[The Journal of Psychology]] 21: 107 to 21</ref> though he also considered the possibility that one of the friendships might breakdown, according to ''balance theory'', which his view of human triangles is called. According to Heider, the friend of a friend contact could be stressful enough to undermine one or another of the friendships. Extending the study of social dynamics caused by such friend-of-a-friend tensions to social networks beyond triangles, D. Cartwright and [[Frank Harary]] used [[signed graph]]s to indicate positive or negative sentiments between persons.<ref>Cartwright, D. and [[Frank Harary]] (1956)[http://snap.stanford.edu/class/cs224w-readings/cartwright56balance.pdf Structural balance: a generalization of Heider's theory], [[Psychological Review]] 63: 277–293 link from [[Stanford University]]</ref> In 1963 [[Anatol Rapoport]] summarized the theory: "The hypothesis implies roughly that attitudes of the group members will change is such a way that one's friends' friends will tend to become one's friends, ..."<ref>[[Anatol Rapoport]] (1963) "Mathematical models of social interaction", in [https://archive.org/details/handbookofmathem017893mbp ''Handbook of Mathematical Psychology'', v. 2], pp 493 to 580, especially 541, editors: R.A. Galanter, R.R. Lace, E. Bush, [[John Wiley & Sons]]</ref> In September 1975 [[Dartmouth College]] offered a symposium<ref>Paul W. Holland & Samuel Leinhardt (editors) (1979) ''Perspectives on Social Network Research'', [[Academic Press]] {{ISBN|9780123525505}}</ref> on these dynamics.
Bo Anderson made an analysis of the friend-of-a-friend relationship in connection with his criticism of balance theory.<ref>Bo Anderson (1979) "Cognitive Balance Theory and Social Network Analysis: Remarks on some fundamental theoretical matters", pages 453–69 in ''Perspectives on Social Network Research'', editors: Paul W. Holland & Samuel Leinhardt, [[Academic Press]], see page 458.</ref> :We have all encountered cases in which somebody has said, "You should meet so-and-so", only to find that we have little in common with that person, even though he or she was introduced to us by a mutual friend...In ''some'' friendships the persons value the exclusiveness of their relationship and are therefore not likely to let others into it. Friends differ from acquaintances in that they are not merely slots in a grid of social network relationships, but are valued for their personal, ''unique'' qualities. Hence, when I relate to a friend of a friend, I need to know something about the perceptions and exchanges that make up this friendship. My reaction to my friend's friend (or spouse) may even be ''unfavorable'', although I may ''also'' well understand and sympathize with my friend’s affection for her, given ''his'' needs, perceptions, interests and so on.
Considering [[friendship]] between people to be a [[binary relation]], the connection to a friend of a friend is a [[composition of relations|composition]] of the relationship with itself. Composed relations are used to describe [[kinship#Composition of relations|kinship]], so it may be natural to apply composition to friendship. One consequence is that frequently a person's friends have more friends than him (the [[friendship paradox]]), which accents the reach of the compound connection. But the fact that friendship is not automatically a [[transitive relation]] produces some social dynamics.
==Meme== '''Friend of a friend''' ('''FOAF''') is a phrase used to refer to someone that one does not know well, literally, a friend of a friend.
In some [[social sciences]], the phrase is used as a half-joking shorthand for the fact that much of the information on which people act comes from distant sources (as in "It happened to a friend of a friend of mine") and cannot be confirmed.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Goodreau SM, Kitts JA, Morris M |title=Birds of a feather, or friend of a friend? Using exponential random graph models to investigate adolescent social networks |journal=Demography |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=103–25 |year=2009 |pmid=19348111 |pmc=2831261 |doi=10.1353/dem.0.0045}}</ref> It is probably best known from [[urban legend]] studies, where it was popularized by [[Jan Harold Brunvand]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intropsych.com/ch01_psychology_and_science/urban_legends.html|title=Urban Legends - in Chapter 01: Psychology and Science - from Psychology: An Introduction by Russ Dewey|website=www.intropsych.com|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>{{self-published-inline|date=May 2014}}
The acronym ''FOAF'' was coined by [[Rodney Dale]] and used in his 1978 book ''The Tumour in the Whale: A Collection of Modern Myths''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Urban Legends, Updated and Expanded Edition|first=Jan Harold|last=Brunvand|authorlink=Jan Harold Brunvand|page=241|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9xOb-19lXx8C&pg=PA241}}</ref>
==Other languages== * "Dúirt bean liom go ndúirt bean léi" [[q:Irish proverbs|(Irish proverb)]] – similar [[Irish language]] term literally meaning ''a woman told me that a woman told her that...'' * "L'homme qui a vu l'homme qui a vu l'ours" [[q:French proverbs|(French proverb)]] – similar [[French language]] proverb literally meaning ''The man who saw the man who saw the bear'', in which the bear is never seen, only heard of.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lhomme_qui_a_vu_lhomme_qui_a_vu_lours_2013/|title=L'homme qui a vu l'homme qui a vu l'ours|publisher=|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reviews/movies|title=Movie Reviews|date=13 February 2018|publisher=|accessdate=14 February 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> * "Un amigo me dijo que un amigo le dijo..." [[q:Spanish proverbs|(Spanish proverb)]] – meaning literally ''A friend told me that a friend told him that...'' *"Jedna paní povídala..." [[q: Czech proverbs|(Czech proverb)]] – similar [[Czech language]] proverb literally meaning ''One lady said...'' * "Teman kepada teman saya..." [[Indonesian language|Bahasa Indonesia]]; literally meaning ''friend of my friend''. * "Babaturana babaturan urang..." [[Sundanese language|Basa Sunda]]; literally meaning ''friend of my friend''. There is another version of this phrase in Sundanese language, "''Babaturan dulur urang''", which means "friend of my relatives". * "카더라..." [[Korean language|Korean]]; [[Gyeongsang dialect]] word literally meaning ''Who said that...'' * "Diz-se que..." or "Dizem que..." [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]; literally meaning ''It is said that...'' or ''They say that...'' * "Freundesfreund" [[German language|German]]; literally meaning ''a friend's friend'' * "Umgani womgani wami" [[IsiZulu language]]; meaning ''my friends friend''

{{more footnotes|date=November 2015}} [[Image:DancingAtGaskellBall.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Dancers at The Gaskell Ball]]
The '''Gaskell Ball''' is a [[Victorian era|Victorian]]-styled [[Ball (dance)|ball]] held by Ye Gaskell Occasional Dance Society in [[Oakland, California]], United States, popular among historical re-creationists and [[vintage dance]] enthusiasts.
The ball came to be over 25 years ago, as an offshoot of a dance portion of the Great Dickens Christmas Fair held in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ye Gaskell Occasional Dance Society|author=Liz Scott|publisher=Santa Cruz Sentinel, The Guide|date=16 February 2007|url=http://adserver1.harvestadsdepot.com/stcruzsentnl/ss/059096/014/014_001/014_001.shtml}}</ref>
The event was held at [[Oakland, California|Oakland]]'s Scottish Rite Center on the shore of [[Lake Merritt]] every two months through the end of 2014. Due to the increased costs of the hall, the event has become less frequent; only one ball was held in 2015, in October. Music for the event is provided by "Brassworks", a popular local band. The evening includes a basic vintage waltz lesson for early attendees and some small potluck refreshments. Dances are taught during a brief course before the ball begins, and include vintage [[waltz]], [[schottische]], [[polka]], [[mazurka]], and several [[English country dance]]s. Occasionally, groups will form on the sidelines to dance alternate arrangements to the English Country songs; previous examples include [[Irish dance|Irish four-hand reels]], the [[Scottish country dance]] "Petronella", the [[Virginia reel (dance)|Virginia reel]], and various [[Contra dance]]s. Full Victorian dress is not required; the dress code is formal wear of the nineteenth or twentieth centuries. A minimum of semi-formal attire is requested by the ball staff. Although seldom exercised, the staff reserves the right to refuse entrance to those who are inappropriately attired. There are occasional performances by local dance troupes during the intermission, however there is no official dance group affiliated with the ball.
The Gaskell Ball is a favorite among dancers from the [[Stanford]], [[UC Berkeley]] and [[UC Santa Cruz]] social dance circles, and is widely credited for popularizing John Hertz's ''[[Congress of Vienna Waltz]]'' and [[Richard Powers (dance historian)|Richard Powers]]' ''[[Bohemian National Polka]]'' choreographies.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
==History== The Gaskell Ball is named for the British writer [[Elizabeth Gaskell]]. The Gaskell Ball originated in 1979, when the troupe playing the Gaskell family at the [[The Great Dickens Christmas Fair and Other Victorian Holiday Party|Charles Dickens Fair]] decided to hold a ball in her honor. The first ball was held at [[Mills College]], a women's college in Oakland. In proceeding years it was held at the Veterans' Auditorium in Oakland. In the 1990s the ball outgrew the hall and was moved to accommodate the increased attendance.

{{good article}} {{Infobox song | name = Get Your Gunn | cover = Get Your Gunn.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]] | album = [[Portrait of an American Family]] | B-side = Revelation #9 | released = {{Start date|1994|6|9}} | format = [[CD single|CD]] | recorded = {{hlist|[[Criteria Studios]], [[Miami]]|[[The Village (studio)|The Village Recorder]], [[West Los Angeles]]}} | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Gothic rock]]|[[hard rock]]}} | length = 3:18 | label = {{hlist|[[Nothing Records|Nothing]]|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]}} | writer = {{hlist|[[Marilyn Manson]]|[[Scott Putesky|Daisy Berkowitz]]|[[Gidget Gein]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Trent Reznor]]|Manson}} | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[Lunchbox (song)|Lunchbox]] | next_year = 1995 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|phjXoYqYE2U|"Get Your Gunn"}}}} }}
"'''Get Your Gunn'''" is a song by American rock band [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]], released as the [[lead single]] from their debut [[studio album]], ''[[Portrait of an American Family]]'' (1994). The song was written by the band's [[Marilyn Manson|eponymous vocalist]] along with original guitarist and bassist [[Daisy Berkowitz]] and [[Gidget Gein]], respectively, and was [[Record producer|produced]] by Manson with [[Trent Reznor]]. "Get Your Gunn" was inspired by the [[murder of David Gunn|murder]] of [[abortion in the United States|abortion]]ist [[David Gunn (doctor)|David Gunn]] by a [[United States pro-life movement|pro-life]] activist, an event which angered Manson.
A [[gothic rock]] and [[hard rock]] song, the track received a mostly positive response from music critics, who described it as both nightmarish and well-produced, while Manson garnered acclaim for his vocal performance. The song features [[saxophone]] played by [[Sugarsmack]] vocalist [[Hope Nicholls]], and an audio sample of the televised suicide of [[R. Budd Dwyer]]. According to Berkowitz, the writing of the song marked a change of direction for Manson, after which he began to write more politically-charged songs. "Get Your Gunn" was blamed by the [[far-right politics|far-right]] in the United States for the [[Columbine High School massacre]], and multiple critics have deemed it one of the most controversial songs of all time. Its [[music video]] was directed by Rod Chong and released in 1994. The clip garnered acclaim from critics, and the song reached number 11 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]], three years after its initial release.
==Background and release== [[File:Michael Griffin.jpg|thumb|left|upright|150px|Michael Frederick Griffin (''pictured'') [[Murder of David Gunn|murdered David Gunn]]; the murder inspired "Get Your Gunn".]] Abortionist [[David Gunn (doctor)|David Gunn]] was [[Murder of David Gunn|shot and killed in 1993]] at an anti-abortion protest by Michael Frederick Griffin, a [[Christian fundamentalism|Christian fundamentalist]]. At his trial, Griffin claimed to have been manipulated into killing Gunn by John Burt, a [[United States pro-life movement|pro-life]] leader and former member of the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. Gunn's death was, in the words of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''{{'}}s [[Dahlia Lithwick]], "the first targeted killing of an abortion doctor in America".<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/14/us/the-clinic-gunman-and-the-victim-abortion-fight-reflected-in-2-lives.html |title=The Clinic Gunman and the Victim: Abortion Fight Reflected in 2 Lives |author=Sara Rimer |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 14, 1993 |accessdate=January 17, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428002621/http://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/14/us/the-clinic-gunman-and-the-victim-abortion-fight-reflected-in-2-lives.html |archivedate=April 28, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2017/10/michael-frederick-griffin-killed-an-abortion-doctor-he-could-soon-be-a-free-man.html| last=Lithwick| first=Dahlia| title=The Murderer Who Started a Movement| publisher=''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''| date=October 31, 2017| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171102203809/https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2017/10/michael-frederick-griffin-killed-an-abortion-doctor-he-could-soon-be-a-free-man.html| archivedate=November 2, 2017| df=}}</ref> The murder inspired "Get Your Gunn", hence the spelling of the song's title. Manson told ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' in 1999 that Gunn's death "was the ultimate hypocrisy I witnessed growing up: that these people killed someone in the name of being 'prolife.'"<ref name=rs/>
Manson has said that the murder "almost made me laugh, but it made me mad. When you think about it, it's so fucking backwards, despite the whole Christian belief of [[Matthew 5:44|love thy enemy]] and all that."<ref name=pheonix>{{cite web| url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/music/marilyn-manson-i-like-to-smoke-and-hang-out-with-the-gangsta-rappers-6615701| last=Louvau| first=Jim| title=Marilyn Manson: "I Like To Smoke and Hang Out With The Gangsta Rappers"| publisher=''[[Phoenix New Times]]''| date=May 30, 2013| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319044000/http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/music/marilyn-manson-i-like-to-smoke-and-hang-out-with-the-gangsta-rappers-6615701| archivedate=March 19, 2016| df=}}</ref> When writing the track, Manson also drew inspiration from his longtime fascination with [[abortion]].<ref name=book/> Commenting on both "Get Your Gunn" and "[[Lunchbox (song)|Lunchbox]]", Manson noted that "The somewhat positive messages of these songs are usually the ones that sensationalists misinterpret as promoting the very things I am decrying."<ref name=rs>{{cite magazine|author=Marilyn Manson|title=Columbine: Whose Fault Is It?|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|issue=815|date=June 24, 1999|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/columbine-whose-fault-is-it-19990624|access-date=April 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721192522/http://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/columbine-whose-fault-is-it-19990624|archivedate=July 21, 2012|df=}}</ref>
When deciding the direction of ''Portrait of an American Family'', Manson and band-mate [[Scott Putesky|Daisy Berkowitz]] deicided that it would comment on what they saw as the hypocrisy of the U.S. media. Discussing "Get Your Gunn" with ''[[Vice (magazine)|Noisey]]'' in 2014, Berkowitz said: "When we started out [Manson's lyricism] was more psychedelic. It was weirdness. We played up weirdness rather than anything socially pointed. We got more social and political as things went on. Like with our song, 'Get Your Gunn' that definitely wasn't something that we started out doing."<ref name=vice>{{cite web| url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/65aab6/daisy-berkowitz-marilyn-manson-scott-putesky-interview-1| last=Tron| first=Gina| title=Daisy Berkowitz: Portrait of an American Ex-Marilyn Manson Member| publisher=''[[Vice (magazine)|Noisey]]''| date=April 14, 2014| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171113124905/https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/65aab6/daisy-berkowitz-marilyn-manson-scott-putesky-interview-1| archivedate=November 13, 2017| df=}}</ref>
Manson has said that "Get Your Gunn" is his favorite song from ''Portrait of an American Family''.<ref name=pheonix/> Manson told the ''[[Sun-Sentinel]]'' that "What's great is that ["Get Your Gunn"] is the most uncommercial track, the most politically incorrect."<ref name=sun/> "Snake Eyes and Sissies" was originally planned to be the band's debut single, but "Get Your Gunn" was released instead<ref name=team/> on June 9, 1994.<ref name=allmusic/> The single featured "Get Your Gunn" and "Misery Machine", another song from ''Portrait of an American Family'', as well as two other tracks: "Mother Inferior Got Her Gunn" and "Revelation #9". The titles of the two latter songs are puns based on songs from the [[The Beatles (album)|White Album]].<ref name=allmusic/> The child pictured on the sleeve for the disc is Wes Brown, the half-brother of [[Twiggy Ramirez]].<ref name=twiggy>{{cite book |first=Kurt |last=Reighley |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LZtVCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=noisey+manson+get+your+gunn&source=bl&ots=vRh-BikqYH&sig=d7t1kZbL61KLhbrB7rwXacrOAyY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGmo2zt-DYAhXM0FMKHTNgANwQ6AEITTAJ#v=onepage&q=wes%20brown&f=false |title=Marilyn Manson |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]] |date=April 15, 1998 |page=45 |accessdate=2018-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120234007/https://books.google.com/books?id=LZtVCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=noisey+manson+get+your+gunn&source=bl&ots=vRh-BikqYH&sig=d7t1kZbL61KLhbrB7rwXacrOAyY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGmo2zt-DYAhXM0FMKHTNgANwQ6AEITTAJ#v=onepage&q=wes%20brown&f=false |archivedate=January 20, 2018 |df= }}</ref>
==Composition== [[File:R. Budd Dwyer.jpg|thumb|right|upright|"Get Your Gunn" features audio of [[R. Budd Dwyer]]'s suicide.]] {{Listen|pos=left|filename=Marilyn Manson - Get Your Gunn.ogg|title="Get Your Gunn"|description=An 18-second sample of "Get Your Gunn", a [[gothic rock]] and [[hard rock]] song.|format =[[Ogg]]}} "Get Your Gunn" is a [[gothic rock]]<ref name=goth/> and [[hard rock]] song<ref name=stereogum/> with a length of three minutes and eighteen seconds.<ref name=allmusic/> The song's lyrics were written by the band's [[Marilyn Manson|eponymous vocalist]], while its music was written by [[Scott Putesky|Daisy Berkowitz]] and [[Gidget Gein]]; the track was produced by Manson and [[Trent Reznor]].<ref name=notes/> The aforementioned murder is reflected in its lyrics "God damn your righteous hand/ I eat innocent meat/ The housewife I will beat/ The prolife I will kill".<ref name=gigwise/> Alec Chillingworth of ''[[Metal Hammer]]'' found the song's "wacky, stomping hook" reminiscent of the music of [[Jack Off Jill]].<ref name=jack/>
Joseph Schafer of ''[[Stereogum]]'' described Manson's vocals on the track as raspy and unpolished, as well as reminiscent of [[Maynard James Keenan]]'s vocals on [[Tool (band)|Tool]]'s EP ''[[Opiate (EP)|Opiate]]'' (1992).<ref name=stereogum/> Schafer saw similarities between the riff in the song's verses and the music of [[Helmet (band)|Helmet]], and thought that the [[snare drum]]s and [[cymbals]] in the song's chorus evoke the work of artists signed to [[Wax Trax! Records]], particularly [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]].<ref name=stereogum/> The chorus of "Get Your Gunn" is "Goddamn/oh Lord/ goddamn".<ref name=twiggy/> The bridge of "Get Your Gunn" includes audio from the televised [[press conference]] where American politician [[R. Budd Dwyer]] shot himself, including the sound of the gunshot that killed him.<ref name=pheonix/><ref name=book/> When Manson sampled the audio of Dwyer's suicide, [[Richard Patrick]] of [[Nine Inch Nails]] heard the sample and was excited by it; Manson believes that this interaction inspired Patrick to write "[[Hey Man Nice Shot]]" (1995), a song about Dwyer's suicide.<ref name=pheonix/>
Additional [[saxophone]] playing on "Get Your Gunn" is provided by [[Sugarsmack]] vocalist [[Hope Nicholls]].<ref name=book>{{cite book |first=Kurt |last=Reighley |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Marilyn_Manson.html?id=rFd0xYYNSGcC |title=Marilyn Manson |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]] |date=Apr 15, 1998 |page=52 |accessdate=2013-03-23}}</ref> The track features Manson singing "Pseudo-morals work real well, On the talk shows for the weak, But your selective judgements, And goodguy badges, Don't mean a fuck to me".<ref name=clash>{{cite web| url=http://www.clashmusic.com/features/a-bluffers-guide-to-marilyn-manson| author=[[Astroid Boys]]| title=A Bluffer's Guide To Marilyn Manson| publisher=''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]''| date=September 17, 2017| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118132627/http://www.clashmusic.com/features/a-bluffers-guide-to-marilyn-manson| archivedate=January 18, 2018| df=}}</ref> The ''Sun-Sentinel''{{'s}} Sandra Schulman said that the song features "searing lyrics on the mixed message morals of authority."<ref name=sun>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-07-17/entertainment/9407140333_1_marilyn-manson-serial-killers-band|last=Schulman|first=Sandra|title=Manson Dwells On Dark Side|publisher=''[[Sun-Sentinel]]''|date=July 17, 1994|accessdate=January 18, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119120217/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-07-17/entertainment/9407140333_1_marilyn-manson-serial-killers-band|archivedate=January 19, 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Critical reception and controversy== [[File:Robin Thicke 2012 cropped.jpg|thumb|left|upright|150px|"Get Your Gunn" created controversy comparable to that sparked by "[[Blurred Lines]]" (2013) by [[Robin Thicke]].]] Schafer of ''Stereogum'' ranked the song eighth on his list of "The 10 Best Marilyn Manson Songs", saying that "While the remainder of ''Portrait Of An American Family'' comes across as undercooked, even for an early-'90s alt-metal album, 'Get Your Gunn' feels lean and vitriolic. Sadly, Manson seldom matched its aggression again." Schafer also praised Manson's "charming" vocal performance on the song.<ref name=stereogum>{{cite web| url=https://www.stereogum.com/1792094/the-10-best-marilyn-manson-songs/franchises/10-best-songs/| last=Schafer| first=Joseph| title=The 10 Best Marilyn Manson Songs| publisher=''[[Stereogum]]''| date=April 5, 2015| accessdate=December 17, 2017| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709164025/http://www.stereogum.com/1792094/the-10-best-marilyn-manson-songs/franchises/10-best-songs/| archivedate=July 9, 2017| df=}}</ref> Jim Louvau of the ''Phoenix New Times'' named it one of his favorite Marilyn Manson songs alongside "[[Long Hard Road Out of Hell]]" (1997).<ref name=pheonix/> [[Bloody Disgusting]]'s [[Brad Miska]] opined that "In retrospect, its level of cheese is of legend, but in 1994 ''Portrait'' was some dark and weird shit (see 'Cake and Sodomy', 'My Monkey', 'Get Your Gun' {{sic}}, etc.)."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/3324933/from-worst-to-best-marilyn-mansons-albums/3/| last=Miska| first=Brad| title=[Ranked] Marilyn Manson’s Albums!| publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]| date=April 19, 2014| accessdate=January 16, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814174231/http://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/3324933/from-worst-to-best-marilyn-mansons-albums/3/| archivedate=August 14, 2017| df=}}</ref> ''[[Gigwise]]'' said that the song has "brutal" lyrics which "set the precedent for the rest of the band's career".<ref name=gigwise>{{cite web| url=https://www.gigwise.com/photos/56046/The-20-Most-Controversial-Songs-Of-All-Time| title=The 20 Most Controversial Songs Of All Time| publisher=''[[Gigwise]]''| date=April 26, 2010| accessdate=January 18, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401013658/https://www.gigwise.com/photos/56046/The-20-Most-Controversial-Songs-Of-All-Time| archivedate=April 1, 2016| df=}}</ref>
Writing for ''Metal Hammer'', Alec Chillingworth said that "'Lunchbox', 'Get Your Gunn', 'Wrapped In Plastic' and '[[Dope Hat]]' are the catchiest [songs on the album]".<ref name=jack>{{cite web| url=http://teamrock.com/feature/2016-11-14/marilyn-manson-albums-ranked-worst-best| last=Chillingworth| first=Alec| title=Every Marilyn Manson Album, Ranked From Worst To Best| publisher=''[[Metal Hammer]]''| date=November 14, 2014| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119181304/http://teamrock.com/feature/2016-11-14/marilyn-manson-albums-ranked-worst-best| archivedate=November 19, 2016| df=}}</ref> In a piece they wrote for ''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]'', the [[Astroid Boys]] deemed "Get Your Gunn" one of their "personal favourites" from Marilyn Manson's catalogue and praised its lyrics for capturing the hypocrisy in Gunn's murder.<ref name=clash/> Jon Wiederhorn of ''[[Loudwire]]'' praised the track for "driving the record" and helping the band to retain the loyal fan-base that it had cultivated prior to the release of ''Portrait of an American Family''.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://loudwire.com/marilyn-manson-portrait-of-an-american-family-album-anniversary/| last=Wiederhorn| first=Jon| title=23 Years Ago: Marilyn Manson Issues 'Portrait of an American Family'| publisher=''[[Loudwire]]''| date=July 19, 2017| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501054342/http://loudwire.com/marilyn-manson-portrait-of-an-american-family-album-anniversary/| archivedate=May 1, 2017| df=}}</ref>
Sandra Schulman of the ''Sun-Sentinel'' said that the song is "Horrifyingly good, loopy music, with discordant riffs that crawl under your skin and stay there. The soundtrack to every nightmare you've ever had."<ref name=sun/> ''[[Dazed]]''{{'}}s Daisy Jones described "Get Your Gunn", [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s "[[Rape Me]]" (1993), [[The Prodigy]]'s "[[Smack My Bitch Up]]" (1997) and [[Lady Gaga]] and [[R. Kelly]]'s "[[Do What U Want]]" (2013) as "tracks that provoked, thrilled and shocked their listeners."<ref name=dazed>{{cite web| url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/music/article/28329/1/the-most-controversial-tracks-of-all-time| last=Jones| first=Daisy| title=The most controversial tracks of all time| publisher=''[[Dazed]]''| date=November 11, 2015| accessdate=January 18, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119060646/http://www.dazeddigital.com/music/article/28329/1/the-most-controversial-tracks-of-all-time| archivedate=January 19, 2018| df=}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[AllMusic]] wrote that "Even though it wasn't one of the best tracks on ''Portrait of an American Family'', 'Get Your Gunn' was a solid track that was a fairly good choice for a single."<ref name=allmusic>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/get-your-gunn-mw0000625988|title=Get Your Gunn – Marilyn Manson|author=Erlewine, Stephen Thomas|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=January 16, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716000031/http://www.allmusic.com/album/get-your-gunn-mw0000625988|archivedate=July 16, 2017|df=}}</ref> Conversely, ''[[The Chicago Maroon]]''{{'s}} Matt Zakosek called the track "weary Goth-rock junk" and criticized its inclusion on the [[greatest hits album]] ''[[Lest We Forget: The Best Of]]'' (2004).<ref name=goth>{{cite web| url=https://www.chicagomaroon.com/article/2004/10/17/a-shocking-thing-about-manson-cd-it-doesnt-suck/| last=Zakosek| first=Matt| title=A shocking thing about Manson CD: It doesn't suck| publisher=''[[The Chicago Maroon]]''| date=October 17, 2004| accessdate=January 18, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120234007/https://www.chicagomaroon.com/article/2004/10/17/a-shocking-thing-about-manson-cd-it-doesnt-suck/| archivedate=January 20, 2018| df=}}</ref>
In America, the [[Far-right politics|far-right]] blamed the [[Columbine High School massacre]] on "Get Your Gunn"; Manson responded to this claim by saying that "In my work I examine the America we live in, and I've always tried to show people that the devil we blame our atrocities on is really just each one of us." Due to its association with the Columbine massacre, Daisy Jones of ''Dazed'' placed "Get Your Gunn" on her list of the most controversial songs of all time, though she deemed the association absurd. Jones wrote that the song created an amount of controversy comparable to that sparked by "[[Fuck tha Police]]" (1988) by [[N.W.A]] and "[[Blurred Lines]]" (2013) by [[Robin Thicke]].<ref name=dazed/> Similarly, a [[PRS for Music]] survey conducted in 2010 revealed that the British public considered "Get Your Gunn" the eighth most controversial song of all time,<ref>{{cite press |date=23 November 2010 |title=Ozzy, Manson, Rage Make Top Ten Controversial Songs List |url=http://www.prsformusic.com/aboutus/press/latestpressreleases/Pages/UKPublicVotesProdigySongAsMostControversial.aspx |publisher=[[PRS for Music]] |accessdate=2011-09-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828191525/http://www.prsformusic.com/aboutus/press/latestpressreleases/Pages/UKPublicVotesProdigySongAsMostControversial.aspx |archivedate=28 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> while Schafer of ''Stereogum'' noted in 2015 that it was "still one of the most controversial songs in Manson’s repertoire".<ref name=stereogum/> ''Gigwise'' ranked the track fifteenth on their list of "The 20 Most Controversial Songs of All Time".<ref name=gigwise/>
==Music video== The music video, directed by Rod Chong, features Manson performing in an abandoned house. It is one of four Marilyn Manson music videos where the band's frontman has eyebrows.<ref name=team>{{cite web| url=http://teamrock.com/feature/2016-01-05/the-13-best-marilyn-manson-videos| last=Young| first=Simon| title=The 13 best Marilyn Manson videos| publisher=[[Metal Hammer|Team Rock]]| date=January 5, 2016| accessdate=January 18, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119001152/http://teamrock.com/feature/2016-01-05/the-13-best-marilyn-manson-videos| archivedate=January 19, 2018| df=}}</ref> The video was accepted by MTV. Although it was rarely aired by the network, it was shown on ''[[Headbangers Ball]]''. Manson told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that MTV wanted to censor the use of the word "goddamn" in the track's chorus, commenting "They wanted the word God bleeped, which is assbackward because damn is the cussword."<ref name=twiggy/> The clip focuses on Manson's eyes, and features imagery of light coming in through windows.<ref name=sun/>
Simon Young of [[Metal Hammer|Team Rock]] called the "Get Your Gunn" video one of the band's "classic videos".<ref name=team/> Sandra Shulman of the ''Sun-Sentinel'' called the video "a searing and tight piece of work".<ref name=sun/> Dan Epstein of ''[[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]]'' wrote that "Marilyn Manson might be best known as a musician, but he's also made his mark as a video artist, simultaneously captivating and disgusting viewers since 1994's 'Get Your Gunn' clip all the way up to this year's nympho-nuns-with-guns visual '[[We Know Where You Fucking Live]]'."<ref name=revolver>{{cite web|work= [[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]]|url= https://www.revolvermag.com/culture/5-most-horrifying-moments-marilyn-manson-music-videos#1-beautiful-people-1996|first= Dan|last= Epstein|title= 5 Most Horrifying Moments From Marilyn Manson Music Videos|date= July 17, 2014|accessdate= December 10, 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171211104958/https://www.revolvermag.com/culture/5-most-horrifying-moments-marilyn-manson-music-videos#1-beautiful-people-1996|archivedate= December 11, 2017|df= }}</ref> [[MTV]]'s Rob Mancini viewed the video for "Get Your Gunn" as one of Marilyn Manson's "early nuggets".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1431699/marilyn-manson-plans-live-album-home-video/| last=Mancini| first=Rob| title=Marilyn Manson Plans Live Album, Home Video| publisher=[[MTV]]| date=September 7, 1999| accessdate=January 17, 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118122613/http://www.mtv.com/news/1431699/marilyn-manson-plans-live-album-home-video/| archivedate=January 18, 2018| df=}}</ref>
==In popular culture== "Get Your Gunn" appeared on the soundtracks for the films ''[[S.F.W.]]'' (1994)<ref name=book/> and ''[[Strange Days (film)|Strange Days]]'' (1995).<ref>{{cite book|first=John Kenneth|last=Muir|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AHoTII8bSu4C&pg=PA266&lpg=PA266&dq=get+your+gunn+strange+days&source=bl&ots=hEU3tUKZW6&sig=fZ3cm8bxg4zQQwr1DM3QlkCSwD0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwid743n7-LYAhUBbK0KHQKRCywQ6AEIWDAL#v=onepage&q=get%20your%20gunn%20strange%20days&f=false|title=The Rock & Roll Film Encyclopedia|publisher=Applause Theatre & Cinema Books|page=266|accessdate=2018-01-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120234007/https://books.google.com/books?id=AHoTII8bSu4C&pg=PA266&lpg=PA266&dq=get+your+gunn+strange+days&source=bl&ots=hEU3tUKZW6&sig=fZ3cm8bxg4zQQwr1DM3QlkCSwD0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwid743n7-LYAhUBbK0KHQKRCywQ6AEIWDAL#v=onepage&q=get%20your%20gunn%20strange%20days&f=false|archivedate=2018-01-20|df=}}</ref>
==Track listing== All songs written by Manson, Berkowitz and Gein, except 2 by Manson, Berkowitz, Gein and [[Madonna Wayne Gacy]], and 4 by Manson and Gacy.
* '''CD single''' {{small|(Australia, Europe and United States: IND–95902 · Canada: CINTD–95902 · Japan: MVCT–12009)}} # "Get Your Gunn" {{small|(Album Version)}} – 3:18 # "Misery Machine" {{small|(Album Version)}} – 4:44 # "Mother Inferior Got Her Gunn" {{small|(Remix by Trent Reznor)}} – 5:39 # "Revelation #9" – 12:57
==Personnel== Credits adapted from the liner notes of the "Get Your Gunn" single.<ref name=notes>{{cite AV media notes |title=Get Your Gunn|type=CD liner notes |others=Various|publisher=[[Interscope Records]] |year=1994|id=IND–95902}}</ref>
'''Marilyn Manson''' *[[Marilyn Manson]] – lyrics, production, sleeve concept and band logo *[[Daisy Berkowitz]] – music *[[Gidget Gein]] – music *[[Madonna Wayne Gacy]] – [[brass]] and [[Loop (music)|loop]]s *[[Sara Lee Lucas]] – [[Drum kit|drums]]
'''Additional musicians and technical personnel''' *[[Sean Beavan]] – brass, [[Programming (music)|programming]], digital editing, production and [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]] assistance *[[Charlie Clouser]] – [[drum programming]] and digital editing *Barry Goldberg – engineering assistance *[[Roli Mosimann]] – [[Audio engineer|engineering]] and original production *[[Alan Moulder]] – engineering, production and mixing assistance *[[Hope Nicholls]] – [[saxophone]] *Robin Perrine – photography *[[Trent Reznor]] – [[executive producer]], mixing *[[Gary Talpas]] – package design *[[Chris Vrenna]] – [[Percussion instrument|percussion]], programming, engineering assistance
==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- !scope="col"| Chart (1997–98) !scope="col"| Peak<br />position |- !scope="row"| Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]])<ref>{{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988–2010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia}}</ref> | 97 |- !scope="row"| Canada (''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'')<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-canada-digital-song-sales/1997-05-10 |title=Canadian Singles Chart {{!}} May 10, 1997 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 10, 1997 |accessdate=October 5, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120234007/https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-canada-digital-song-sales/1997-05-10 |archivedate=January 20, 2018 |df= }}</ref> | 11 |- |}
==See also== *[[List of songs recorded by Marilyn Manson]] *[[Marilyn Manson–Columbine High School massacre controversy]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |last= |first= |year=2002 |title=The Children's Folklore Review, Volume 24-27 |page=49 |publisher=[[East Carolina University]] |isbn= }} *{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Paul |year=1996 |title=Boys: Masculinities in Contemporary Culture |url= |page=182 |publisher=[[Westview Press]] |isbn= }}
==External links== * {{Youtube|phjXoYqYE2U|"Get Your Gunn"}} * [http://www.mansonwiki.com/wiki/Get_Your_Gunn_(single) "Get Your Gunn"] on [http://www.mansonwiki.com/ MansonWiki.com] * {{Discogs release|type=single |id=544613 |name=Get Your Gunn}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} '''Grampians Grape Escape''' is one of the longest running food and wine festivals in Australia and a hallmark event for Victoria. It was launched in 1992.
Held in the [[Grampians National Park]] at [[Halls Gap]] during the first weekend of May every year, the Grampians Grape Escape provides food and wine offerings by more than 100 local artisan producers, live music and family entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vic.gov.au/news/2014-grampians-grape-escape.html|title=2014 Grampians Grape Escape|work=www.vic.gov.au|accessdate=31 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205213229/http://www.vic.gov.au/news/2014-grampians-grape-escape.html|archivedate=5 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Grampians Wine == The festival features [[Grampians_(wine)]] produced by some of the oldest vines in the word; the area was first vinified in 1862 with plantings at Concongella Creek and Great Western by French winemaker Charles Pierlot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grampianswine.com.au/wine_region.html|title=grampians wine... nothing short of spectacular! - wine region|work=grampianswine.com.au|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref> Each year participating wineries select a parcel of wine from the year's vintage for inclusion in the special release Grampians Reserve Shiraz, which is auctioned exclusively at the Festival. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theweeklyadvertiser.com.au/2011/04/27/winemakers-set-for-20th-auction/|title=Winemakers set for 20th auction|work=theweeklyadvertiser.com.au|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref>
== Grape Stomping == Up to a tonne of grapes are donated to the Festival each year by local vineyards and picked by school students for a traditional grape stomping competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.araratadvertiser.com.au/story/2284326/grape-stomp-a-premier-event/|title=Grape Stomp a premier event|author=Fairfax Regional Media|date=15 May 2014|work=The Ararat Advertiser|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref>
==History== The Festival commenced in 1992 as the Halls Gap Gourmet Weekend and was rebranded as Grampians Grape Escape in 2002. It celebrated its 21st year over 5–6 May 2012 and has grown to attract a crowd of up to 10,000 foodies from across the world. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winecompanion.com.au/news/news-articles/2012/february/grampians-grape-escape-celebrates-21-years-of-indulgence|title=Grampians Grape Escape celebrates 21 years of home-grown wine and food indulgence|work=winecompanion.com.au|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref> Previous Festival identities have included: [[Manu Feildel]], [[Poh Ling Yeow]], [[Tobie Puttock]], [[Ed Halmagyi]], [[Rachel Berger]], [[Rebecca Barnard]], [[Monique Brumby]], Adrian Richardson and Stefano de Pieri.
==Recognition== The Festival is recommended by [[Australian Traveller]] as one of Australia’s top 30 wine and beer festivals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australiantraveller.com/post/30-australian-wine-beer-cider-festivals/|title=30 Australian wine & beer festivals definitely worth a taste|work=Australian traveller magazine|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gge.org.au Grampians Grape Escape website]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
[[Category:Wine-related events]] [[Category:Events in Australia]] [[Category:Food and drink festivals in Australia]] [[Category:Wine festivals in Australia]]

'''Humanitarian [[visa (document)|visa]]s''' are granted by some countries to fulfill their [[Convention relating to the Status of Refugees#Responsibilities of parties to the Refugee Convention|international obligation to protecting refugees from persecution]]. The [[Convention relating to the Status of Refugees]] is often used as the main criteria in assessing whether or not there is a legitimate claim for protection, as this defines a refugee as a person: * who is outside their country of origin or legal residence * who is unable, or unwilling to return to their country of legal residence because of a legitimate fear of persecution regarding their race, religion, nationality, group membership, or a political belief, as defined by the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] * who has not been convicted of a serious crime by a fair tribunal.
Persons primarily seeking better [[economic migrant|economic opportunities]] may reasonably quote war, famine or environmental disasters as their main motive for leaving their countries of legal residence, for which reason humanitarian visas may be difficult to obtain.
==Australia== Humanitarian visas are listed as “Subclass 200”<ref>[http://www.findlaw.com.au/articles/4303/what-are-the-types-of-humanitarian-visas-available.aspx Findlaw Australia article:What are the Types of Humanitarian Visas Available in Australia?]</ref> and have several distinct forms * 201: In-country Special Humanitarian Program Visa * 202: Global Special Humanitarian Program Visa (“SHP”) * 203: Emergency Rescue Visa * 204: Woman at Risk Visa
==European Union== Humanitarian visas are not yet issued by the European Union, but have been recommended by, [[Alexander Betts (academic)|Alexander Betts]], who is the director of the Refugee Studies Centre, University of Oxford. He is the author of a book Survival Migration: Failed Governance and the Crisis of Displacement<ref>{{cite book|title=Survival Migration: Failed Governance and the Crisis of Displacement|author=Alexander Betts|publisher=Cornell University|isbn=978-0801477775|date=2013}}</ref> Betts cites these as an alternative to the current choice for families between * [[refugee camp]]s, which are often makeshift and overcrowded, with minimal facilities for hygiene, [[health care]] or education * dangerous journeys, often arranged by [people smuggler]s at very high cost. * [[urban poverty]] as undocumented entrants working illegally The European Union Migration and Home Affairs directorate is considering establishing a unified agency <ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/what-we-do/policies/asylum/index_en.htm EU Policy:Common European Asylum System]</ref>
==Russian Federation== Humanitarian visas may be issued to stateless persons or citizens from countries such as the USA who may be considered potentially hostile, and traveling to for a variety of reasons including cultural or political exchanges, sports events, scientific or technical conferences and providing temporary specialist services such as humanitarian relief.<ref>[http://ils-usa.com/main.php?id=humanitarian&lang=en Russian Visa Center, USA advice page]</ref>
== USA:Humanitarian parole== Humanitarian visas are also known as humanitarian [[Parole (United States immigration)|parole]] in the USA which are documents granted for short-term urgent humanitarian relief, typically for up to one year. People who would otherwise be unable to enter the U.S. may be granted humanitarian parole in exceptional personal circumstances, but these do not permit them to obtain permanent residency.<ref>[http://traveltips.usatoday.com/humanitarian-visa-108465.html USA Today, What Is a Humanitarian Visa?]</ref>
==See also== <!-- New links in alphabetical order please --> *[[1954 Convention Travel Document]] for stateless persons *[[Certificate of identity]] for stateless persons or others *[[Identity document]] *[[Nansen passport]] the predecessor of the current Refugee travel document *[[Refugee travel document]] issued by the country of origin *[[Travel Document]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Aftermath of war]] [[Category:United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]]
