{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox President | name = Radovan Karadžić | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = RadovanKaradzic.jpg | caption = Karadžić in March 2016 | order = 1st | office = President of Republika Srpska | term_start = 7 April 1992 | term_end = 19 July 1996 | vicepresident = [[Biljana Plavšić]]
[[Nikola Koljević]] | predecessor = ''Position established'' | successor = [[Biljana Plavšić]] | alias = Dr. Dragan David Dabić
Petar Glumac | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1945|06|19}} | birth_place = [[Šavnik]], [[People's Republic of Montenegro|Montenegro]], [[Democratic Federal Yugoslavia|DF Yugoslavia]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[University of Sarajevo]]
[[Columbia Medical School]] | profession = [[Psychiatrist]] | spouse = [[Ljiljana Zelen Karadžić]] | children = 2 | party = [[Serbian Democratic Party (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Serbian Democratic]] | nationality = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian]]{{cite web|url=http://rs.n1info.com/a193703/Vesti/Vesti/Radovan-Karadzic-zatrazio-drzavljanstvo-Srbije.html|title=Radovan Karadžić zatražio državljanstvo Srbije|publisher=N1|date=16 September 2016|language=Serbo-Croatian|accessdate=20 June 2018}} | religion = [[Serbian Orthodox]] | signature = Radovan Karadzic Signature.svg }} '''Radovan Karadžić''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|æ|r|ə|dʒ|ɪ|tʃ}}; {{lang-sr-cyr|Радован Караџић}}, {{IPA-sh|râdoʋaːn kâradʒitɕ|pron}}; born 19 June 1945) is a [[Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian Serb]] former politician and convicted [[war crime|war criminal]] who served as the [[President of Republika Srpska|President]] of [[Republika Srpska]] during the [[Bosnian War]] and sought the unification of that entity with [[Serbia]].''Daily report: East Europe, Issues 191-210''. Front Cover United States. Foreign Broadcast Information Service. p. 38. Trained as a [[psychiatrist]], he co-founded the [[Serb Democratic Party (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Serb Democratic Party]] in Bosnia and Herzegovina and served as the first [[President of Republika Srpska]] from 1992 to 1996. He was a fugitive from 1996 until July 2008 after having been indicted for war crimes by the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7518543.stm|title=Serbia captures fugitive Karadzic|publisher=BBC|date=22 July 2008|accessdate=24 July 2008}} The indictment concluded there were reasonable grounds for believing he committed war crimes, including [[genocide]] against [[Bosniak]] and [[Croats of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Croat]] civilians during the [[Bosnian War]] (1992–95). While a fugitive, he worked at a private clinic in [[Belgrade]], specialising in [[alternative medicine]] and [[psychology]] under an alias.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL22936908|title=Karadzic lived as long-haired, New Age doctor|accessdate=26 July 2008|publisher=Reuters|date=22 July 2008}} His nephew, Dragan Karadžić, has claimed in an interview to the ''[[Corriere della Sera]]'' that Radovan Karadžić attended [[Serie A]] football matches and that he visited [[Venice]] using a different alias (Petar Glumac).{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/esteri/08_luglio_27/karadzic_italia_tifo_inter_517d3d86-5bb0-11dd-b836-00144f02aabc.shtml|title=Mio zio Karadzic in Italia: allo stadio per tifare Inter|work=Corriere della Sera|language=Italian|accessdate=20 December 2010}} [[Trial of Radovan Karadžić|He was arrested]] in Belgrade on 21 July 2008 and brought before Belgrade's War Crimes Court a few days later. Extradited to the [[Netherlands]], he is in the custody of the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] in the [[United Nations Detention Unit]] of [[ICC detention centre|Scheveningen]], where he was charged with 11 counts of [[war crimes]].{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/icty/indictment/english/kar-ai000428e.htm|title=The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia the Prosecutor of the Tribunal Against Radovan Karadzic Amended Indictment|publisher=UN|accessdate=13 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209130506/http://www.un.org/icty/indictment/english/kar-ai000428e.htm|archivedate=9 February 2008}}{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/icty/cases-e/cis/karadzic/CIS-Karadzic.pdf|title=Case Information Sheet|publisher=UN|accessdate=20 July 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325151906/http://www.un.org/icty/cases-e/cis/karadzic/CIS-Karadzic.pdf|archivedate=25 March 2009}} He is sometimes referred to by the Western media as the "Butcher of Bosnia",{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/radovan-karadzic-accused-serbian-war-criminal-captured-1710045.html |title=Yahoo |work=Yahoo |accessdate=5 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130813113039/http://voices.yahoo.com/radovan-karadzic-accused-serbian-war-criminal-captured-1710045.html |archivedate=13 August 2013 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2008/07/22/DI2008072201921.html|work=The Washington Post|first=Olga|last=Kavran|title=Bosnian Serb Leader Radovan Karadzic Arrested: What Lies Ahead|date=23 July 2008}} a [[sobriquet]] also applied to former [[Army of Republika Srpska]] (VRS) General [[Ratko Mladić]].{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/05/26/serbia-arrests-man-believed-ratko-mladic|work=Fox News|title=Serbia Arrests 'Butcher of Bosnia' Ratko Mladic for Alleged War Crimes|date=26 May 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/world/2011/May/Butcher-of-Bosnia-Arrested-In-Serbia|title='Butcher of Bosnia' Arrested In Serbia|accessdate=5 July 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/26/us-serbia-mladic-idUSTRE74P33820110526|work=Reuters|title=Career soldier Mladic became "butcher of Bosnia"|date=26 May 2011}} On 24 March 2016, he was found guilty of the [[genocide in Srebrenica]], [[war crimes]] and [[crimes against humanity]], 10 of the 11 charges in total, and sentenced to 40 years' imprisonment.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/25/world/europe/radovan-karadzic-verdict.html|title= Radovan Karadzic, a Bosnian Serb, Gets 40 Years Over Genocide and War Crimes |work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=24 March 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/24/europe/karadzic-war-crimes-verdict/index.html|title=Karadzic sentenced to 40 years for genocide|website=CNN|access-date=2016-03-26}} On 22 July 2016 he filed an appeal against his conviction. ==Early life and education== Radovan Karadžić was born on 19 June 1945 in the village of [[Petnjica, Šavnik|Petnjica]] in the [[Socialist Republic of Montenegro]], [[Provisional Government of the Democratic Federal Yugoslavia|Democratic Federal Yugoslavia]], near [[Šavnik]].{{sfn|Donia|2014|p=23}} Karadžić's father, Vuko (1912–1987),{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/dodatni_sadrzaj/clanci.119.html:279208-Necu-da-pogazim-rec|title=Neću da pogazim reč|publisher=Novosti|date=6 August 2008|accessdate=24 March 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.co.me/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1582:crnogorac-prodao-radovana&Itemid=2062|title=Crnogorac prodao Radovana|publisher=Monitor|date=2 April 2010|accessdate=24 March 2016}} was a cobbler from Petnjica. His mother, Jovanka ({{nee}} Jakić; 1922–2005),{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/umrla-majka-radovana-karadzica/263909.aspx|title=Umrla majka Radovana Karadžića|publisher=Index|date=5 May 2015|accessdate=24 March 2016}} was a peasant girl from [[Pljevlja]]. She married Karadžić's father in 1943, aged twenty.{{sfn|Donia|2014|p=23}} Karadžić claims to be related to the Serbian linguistic reformer [[Vuk Stefanović Karadžić]] (1787–1864), although this claim cannot be confirmed.{{sfn|Donia|2014|p=24}} His father had been a [[Chetnik]] — the army of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]'s [[government-in-exile]] during World War II—and was imprisoned by the post-war communist regime for much of his son's childhood.{{sfn|Donia|2014|p=25}} Karadžić moved to [[Sarajevo]] in 1960 to study psychiatry at the [[University of Sarajevo|Sarajevo University]] School of Medicine.Robert J. Donia. (2014). ''Radovan Karadzic: Architect of the Bosnian Genocide'', p. 27, [[Cambridge University Press]]. {{ISBN|9781107073357}} [[File:Radovan Karadžić 1971 publicity photo.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Publicity photo of Karadžić in 1971]] Karadžić studied [[neurotic disorders]] and [[Major depressive disorder|depression]] at [[Næstved]] Hospital in [[Denmark]] in 1970, and during 1974-1975 he underwent further medical training at [[Columbia University]] in New York.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/07/22/karadzic.profile/index.html|title=Karadzic: Psychiatrist-turned 'Butcher of Bosnia'|accessdate=23 July 2008|date=22 July 2008|publisher=CNN}}{{cite web|url=http://www.moreorless.au.com/killers/karadzic.html|title=Info on graduate studies at Columbia U.|publisher=moreorless.au.com|accessdate=26 July 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726045044/http://www.moreorless.au.com/killers/karadzic.html|archivedate=26 July 2008|df=dmy-all}} After his return to Yugoslavia, he worked in the Koševo Hospital in Sarajevo.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/karadzic/radovan/marketplace.html|title=Karadzic - The Marketplace Massacre And Radovan Karadzic {{!}} The World's Most Wanted Man|website=pbs.org|access-date=25 March 2016}} He was also a poet, influenced by [[Serbia]]n writer [[Dobrica Ćosić]], who encouraged him to go into politics. During his spell as an ecologist, he declared that "Bolshevism is bad, but nationalism is even worse". ==Financial misdeeds== Soon after graduation, Karadžić started working in a treatment centre at the psychiatric clinic of the main Sarajevo hospital, Koševo. According to testimony, he often boosted his income by issuing fake medical and psychological evaluations to healthcare workers who wanted early retirement or to criminals who tried to avoid punishment by pleading insanity.{{cite book|author=Sudetic, Chuck|title=Blood and Vengeance: One Family's Story of the War in Bosnia|year=1999|location=New York|publisher=Penguin Books|accessdate=}} In 1983, Karadžić started working at a hospital in the [[Belgrade]] suburb of [[Voždovac]]. With his partner [[Momčilo Krajišnik]], then manager of a mining enterprise ''Energoinvest'', he managed to get a loan from an agricultural-development fund and they used it to build themselves houses in [[Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Pale]], a Serb town above Sarajevo turned into a ski resort by the government. [[File:Radovan Karadžić 1984 arrest.jpg|thumb|350px|File picture taken upon Karadžić's arrest in November 1984]]On 1 November 1984 the two were arrested for fraud and spent 11 months in detention before their friend [[Nikola Koljević]] managed to bail them out.{{cite book|author=Judah, Tim|title=The Serbs: History, Myth and the Destruction of Yugoslavia|year=1997|location=New Haven and London|publisher=Yale University Press}} Due to a lack of evidence, Karadžić was released and his trial was brought to a halt. The trial was revived and on 26 September 1985 Karadžić was sentenced to three years in prison for [[embezzlement]] and fraud. As he had already spent over a year in detention, Karadžić did not serve the remaining sentence in prison.{{cite web|accessdate=22 July 2008|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Hronika/Uhapshen-Radovan-Karadzic.sr.html|title=Radovan Karadžić captured|publisher=Serbian newspaper Politika}} ==Political life== Following encouragement from [[Dobrica Ćosić]], later the first president of the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], and [[Jovan Rašković]], leader of the [[Serbs of Croatia|Croatian Serbs]], he cofounded the [[Serb Democratic Party (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Serb Democratic Party]] ({{lang|sr-Latn|Srpska Demokratska Stranka}}) in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] in 1989. The party aimed at unifying the Republic's [[Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian Serb]] community and joining Croatian Serbs in leading them in remaining as part of Yugoslavia in the event of secession by those two republics from the federation. Throughout September 1991, the SDS began to establish various "Serb Autonomous Regions" throughout Bosnia-Herzegovina. After the Bosnian parliament voted on sovereignty on 15 October 1991, a separate Serb Assembly was founded on 24 October 1991 in [[Banja Luka]], to exclusively represent the Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The following month, Bosnian Serbs held a [[referendum]] which resulted in an overwhelming vote in favour of staying in a federal state with Serbia and Montenegro, as part of Yugoslavia. In December 1991, a top secret document, ''For the organisation and activity of organs of the Serbs people in Bosnia-Herzegovina in extraordinary circumstances'', was drawn up by the SDS leadership. This was a centralised programme for the takeover of each municipality in the country, through the creation of shadow governments and para-governmental structures through various "crisis headquarters", and by preparing loyalist Serbs for the takeover in co-ordination with the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] (JNA).{{cite book|last=Gow|first=James|title=The Serbian Project and Its Adversaries: A Strategy of War Crimes|year=2003|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|location=Montreal|isbn=1850654999|pages=122–123}} On 9 January 1992, the Bosnian Serb Assembly proclaimed the Republic of the Serb People of Bosnia and Herzegovina (Република српског народа Босне и Херцеговине/Republika srpskog naroda Bosne i Hercegovine). On 28 February 1992, the constitution of the Serb Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina was adopted. It declared that the state's territory included Serb autonomous regions, municipalities, and other Serbian ethnic entities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as "all regions in which the Serbian people represent a minority due to the Second World War genocide" (although how this was established was never specified), and that it was to be a part of the federal Yugoslav state. On 29 February and 1 March 1992 a referendum on the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina from Yugoslavia was held. Many Serbs boycotted the referendum and pro-independence [[Bosniaks]] (Muslims) and [[Croats]] turned out.Nettelfield, Lara J. (2010). ''Courting Democracy in Bosnia and Herzegovina'' (p. 67). [[Cambridge University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-1-58544-226-3}}. ===President of Republika Srpska=== {{Main|Bosnian War}} [[File:Radovan Karadzic ICTY.jpg|left|thumb|Radovan Karadžić]] On 6 and 7 April 1992, Bosnia was recognized as an independent state by the European Community {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/07/world/europe-nods-to-bosnia-not-macedonia.html|work=New York Times|title=Europe Nods to Bosnia, Not Macedonia|last1=Riding|first1=Alan|date=7 April 1992|accessdate=30 December 2015}} and the US.{{cite web|url=https://history.state.gov/countries/bosnia-herzegovina|title=A guide to the United States' history of recognition, diplomatic, and consular relations, by country, since 1776: Bosnia-Herzegovina|publisher=US Department of State, Office of the Historian}} It was admitted to the UN on 22 May 1992.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/members/index.shtml|title=Member States of the United Nations|publisher=United Nations}} Karadžić was voted President of Republika Srpska, the Bosnian Serb administration, in [[Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Pale]] on about 13 May 1992 after the breakup of the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]]. At the time he assumed this position, his ''[[de jure]]'' powers, as described in the constitution of the Bosnian Serb administration, included commanding the [[Army of Republika Srpska|army of the Bosnian Serb administration]] in times of war and peace, and having the authority to appoint, promote and discharge officers of the army. Karadžić made three trips to the UN in New York in February and March 1993 for negotiations on the future of Bosnia.{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/diana/karadzic/3junea.htm|title=Doe v. Karadzic — Appellee's Brief|accessdate=25 July 2008|publisher=Yale University|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515113117/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/diana/karadzic/3junea.htm|archivedate=15 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} He went to Moscow in 1994 for meetings with Russian officials on the Bosnian situation.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/karadzic-arrest-hailed-as-step-towards-serbia-eu-membership/2008/07/22/1216492402328.html|title=Karadzic arrest hailed as step towards Serbia EU membership|accessdate=25 July 2008|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=22 July 2008}} In 1994, the [[Greek Orthodox Church]] declared Karadžić "one of the most prominent sons of our Lord Jesus Christ working for peace", and decorated him with the nine-hundred-year-old Knights' Order of the First Rank of Saint Dionysius of Xanthe.{{cite book|first=Mitja|last=Velikonja|title=Religious separation and political intolerance in Bosnia-Herzegovina|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|year=2003|location=College Station|isbn=978-1-58544-226-3|page=265}} [[Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople|Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew]] announced that "the Serbian people have been chosen by God to protect the western frontiers of Orthodoxy". On Friday 4 August 1995, with a massive Croatian military force [[Operation Storm|poised to attack]] the [[Republic of Serbian Krajina|Serb-held Krajina]] region in central Croatia, Karadžić announced he was removing General [[Ratko Mladić]] from his commandant post and assuming personal command of the VRS himself. Karadžić blamed Mladić for the loss of two key Serb-held towns in western Bosnia that had recently [[Operation Mistral 2|fallen to the Croats]], and he used the loss of the towns as the excuse to announce his surprise command structure changes. General Mladić was demoted to an "adviser". Mladić refused to go quietly, claiming the support of the Bosnian Serb military and the people. Karadžić countered by attempting to pull political rank as well as denouncing Mladić as a "madman", but Mladić's popular support forced Karadžić to rescind his order on 11 August.[http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/special/karadzic/timeline The Hague's Most Wanted – timeline of events]. SETimes.com (21 July 2008). Retrieved 13 November 2010. ===War crimes charges=== Karadžić was accused by the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY) of personal and [[command responsibility]] for numerous war crimes committed against non-Serbs, in his roles as Supreme Commander of the Bosnian Serb armed forces and President of the National Security Council of the Republika Srpska. He was accused by the same authority of being responsible for the deaths of more than 7,500 [[Bosniaks]] (Muslims). Under his direction and command, Bosnian Serb forces initiated the [[Siege of Sarajevo]]. He was accused by the ICTY of ordering the [[Srebrenica genocide]] in 1995, directing Bosnian Serb forces to "create an unbearable situation of total insecurity with no hope of further survival of life" in the UN [[safe area (Bosnian War)|safe area]]. He was also accused by the ICTY of ordering that United Nations personnel be taken hostage in May–June 1995.[http://www.icty.org/x/cases/karadzic/tdec/en/121211_1.pdf Prosecutor v. Radovan Karadžić], Decision of 11 December 2012, [[ICTY]] He was jointly indicted by the [[International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia]] in 1995, along with General [[Ratko Mladić]]. The indictment charged Karadžić on the basis of his individual criminal responsibility (Article 7(1) of the Statute) and superior criminal responsibility (Article 7(3) of the Statute) with: * Five counts of [[crimes against humanity]] (Article 5 of the Statute – extermination, murder, persecutions on political, racial and religious grounds, persecutions, inhumane acts (forcible transfer)); * Three counts of violations of the [[laws or customs of war|laws of war]] (Article 3 of the Statute – murder, unlawfully inflicting terror upon civilians, taking hostages); * One count of grave breaches of the [[Geneva Conventions]] (Article 2 of the Statute – willful killing).{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/icty/glance/karadzic.htm|title=UN Indictment}} * Unlawful [[population transfer|transfer of civilians]] because of religious or national identity.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7520682.stm|publisher=BBC|title=Karadzic will fight extradition|date=23 July 2008|accessdate=4 January 2010}} The United States government offered a $5 million reward for his and [[Ratko Mladić]]'s arrests.{{cite web|url=http://www.rewardsforjustice.net/english/index.cfm?page=Karadzic|title=Rewards for Justice|accessdate=13 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417040300/http://www.rewardsforjustice.net/english/index.cfm?page=Karadzic|archivedate=17 April 2008|df=dmy-all}} ==Fugitive== Authorities missed arresting Karadžić in 1995 when he was an invitee of the United Nations. During his visit to the United Nations in 1993, he was handed a [[service of process]] for a civil claim under the United States of America Code of Laws [[Alien Tort Act]]. The Courts ruled that Karadžić was properly served and the trial was allowed to proceed in [[United States District Court]].''Kadić v. Karadžić'', 70 F.3d 232 (2d Cir. 1995) [[Image:Radovan Karadzic 2008.jpg|thumb|Radovan Karadžić in January 2008, appearing at a medical conference in Belgrade under the alias ''Dr. Dragan David Dabić'', bearded and with his hair in a pony tail.]] Karadžić's ability to evade capture for over a decade increased his esteem among some Bosnian Serbs, despite an alleged deal with [[Richard Holbrooke]].{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7062288.stm|title=Hague probes Karadzic 'deal' claim |publisher= BBC |accessdate=24 July 2008|date=26 October 2007}} Some sources allege that he received protection from the United States as a consequence of the [[Dayton Agreement]].{{cite news|title=Radovan Karadzic 'was under US protection until 2000'|work=The Telegraph|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/serbia/2496948/Karadzic-was-under-US-protection.html |author=Jon Swaine|date=4 August 2008|accessdate=13 July 2015|location=London, UK}} Holbrooke, however, repeatedly denied that such a deal was ever made.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7062288.stm |title=Hague probes Karadzic 'deal' claim|accessdate=13 July 2015|publisher=BBC|author=Nick Hawton|date=26 October 2007}} During his time as fugitive he was helped by several people, including [[Bosko Radonjich]] and in 2001, hundreds of supporters demonstrated in support of Karadžić in his home town.{{cite web|url= http://www.esquire.com/features/radovan-karadzic-1297 |title=Radovan Karadzic: A Deeply Misunderstood Mass Murderer|accessdate=28 July 2008|publisher=Esquire}} In March 2003, his mother Jovanka publicly urged him to surrender.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/jul/01/comment.warcrimes|title=Whatever happened to ... Radovan Karadzic?|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=24 July 2008|date=1 July 2006|first=Iain|last=Hollingshead}} British officials conceded [[military action]] was unlikely to be successful in bringing Karadžić and other suspects to trial, and that putting political pressure on [[Balkans|Balkan]] governments would be more likely to succeed.{{cite web|url=http://www.iiss.org/whats-new/iiss-in-the-press/july-2008/karadzic-snared-by-spy-tip-and-political-will/|title=Karadzic snared by spy tip and political will|publisher=The International Institute For Strategic Studies|accessdate=26 July 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813031615/http://www.iiss.org/whats-new/iiss-in-the-press/july-2008/karadzic-snared-by-spy-tip-and-political-will|archivedate=13 August 2008}} In May 2004, the UN learned that: "the brother of a war crimes suspect allegedly in the process of providing information on Radovan Karadzic and his network to the ICTY, was mistakenly killed in a raid by the Republika Srpska police" and added that "It is being argued that the informer was targeted in order to silence him before he was able to say more."{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/42f736424.pdf|title=Update on Conditions for Return to Bosnia and Herzegovina (2005)|accessdate=13 July 2015|page=3}} In 2005, Bosnian Serb leaders called on Karadžić to surrender, stating that Bosnia and Serbia could not move ahead economically or politically while he remained at large. After a failed raid earlier in May, on 7 July 2005 [[NATO]] troops arrested Karadžić's son, Aleksandar, but released him after 10 days.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4659319.stm|title=Nato troops arrest Karadzic's son|publisher=BBC|date=7 July 2005|accessdate=13 July 2015}} On 28 July, Karadžić's wife, [[Ljiljana Zelen Karadžić|Ljiljana]], made a call for him to surrender after, what she called, "enormous pressure".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4725923.stm|title=Karadzic's wife urges surrender|publisher=BBC|date=29 July 2005|accessdate=4 January 2010}} See also:{{cite web|url=http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2005/07/29/srpski/P05072807.shtml|title=Radovane, predaj se!|publisher=Yugoslavia News|date=29 July 2005|accessdate=13 July 2015}} The BBC reported that Karadžić had been sighted in 2005 near [[Foča]]: "38 km (24 miles) down the road, on the edge of the Sutjeska national park, Radovan Karadžić has just got out of a red Mercedes" and asserted that "Western intelligence agencies knew roughly where they were, but that there was no political will in London or Washington to risk the lives of British, or U.S. agents, in a bid to seize" him and Mladić.{{cite news|title=Why Bosnia's most wanted run free|publisher=BBC|date=28 June 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/7477912.stm|accessdate=13 July 2015}} On 10 January 2008, the BBC reported that the passports of his closest relatives had been seized.{{cite news|publisher=BBC|title=Karadzic family passports seized|date=10 January 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7181568.stm|accessdate=13 July 2015}} On 21 February 2008, at the time [[Kosovo]] [[2008 Kosovo declaration of independence|declared independence]], portraits of Karadžić were on display during [[Belgrade]]'s "[[Kosovo is Serbia protest]]".Photos at {{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1715332_1538115,00.html|title=Belgrade Riots|work=TIME Magazine|accessdate=26 July 2008|date=21 February 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1715332_1538120,00.html|title=Belgrade Riots|work=TIME Magazine|accessdate=26 July 2008|date=21 February 2008}} Since 1999{{Cite news|date=25 July 2008|accessdate=13 July 2015|title=Karadžić became Dabić in 1999|newspaper=B92|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/crimes.php?yyyy=2008&mm=07&dd=25&nav_id=52206|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140422142243/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/crimes.php?yyyy=2008&mm=07&dd=25&nav_id=52206|archivedate=22 April 2014|deadurl=no}} Karadžić had been masquerading as a "[[new age]]" expert in alternative medicine using the fake name "D.D. David" printed on his business cards. The initials apparently stood for "Dragan Dabić"; officials said he was also using the name "Dr. Dragan David Dabić".{{cite news |date=22 July 2008 |title=Karadžić "practiced alternative medicine" |newspaper=B92 |url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2008&mm=07&dd=22&nav_id=52109 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220164417/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2008&mm=07&dd=22&nav_id=52109 |archivedate=20 February 2014 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news |date=22 July 2008 |title=Karadžićevi savjeti: Kod problema sa seksom najbolja je terapija u paru (Karadžić's tips: For problems with sex the best therapy is with couples) |language=Croatian |newspaper=Vijestinet |url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/karadzicevi-savjeti-kod-problema-sa-seksom-najbolja-je-terapija-u-paru/395880.aspx }}{{Cite news |author=Stojanovic, Dusan |date=22 July 2008 |title=Karadzic hid in plain view to elude capture |publisher=WRAL |url=http://www.wral.com/news/national_world/world/story/3250779 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731230240/http://www.wral.com/news/national_world/world/story/3250779/ |archivedate=31 July 2008 |deadurl=yes }} He lectured in front of hundreds of people on alternative medicine. He had his own website, where he offered his assistance in the treatment of [[sexual problems]] and [[Disorder (medicine)|disorders]] by using what he called "Human Quantum Energy".{{cite web |url=http://www.psy-help-energy.com |title=Human Quantum Energy |accessdate=25 July 2008 |publisher=PSY Help Energy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724223555/http://www.psy-help-energy.com/ |archivedate=24 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===Allegedly evading capture in Austria=== There were reports that Karadžić evaded capture in May 2007 in [[Vienna]], where he lived under the name Petar Glumac, posing as a Croatian seller of herbal solutions and ointments. [[Federal Police (Austria)|Austrian police]] talked to him during the raid regarding an unrelated homicide case in the area where Karadžić lived but failed to recognize his real identity. He had obtained a [[Croatian passport]] in the name of Petar Glumac and claimed to be in Vienna for training.{{cite web |url=http://www.apa.at/cms/site/news_item.html?channel=CH0069&doc=CMS1217014246968 |title=Karadzic nannte sich "Peter Schauspieler" |accessdate=26 July 2008 |publisher=Austria Press Agency |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531200419/http://www.apa.at/cms/site/news_item.html?channel=CH0069&doc=CMS1217014246968 |archivedate=31 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The police did not ask any further questions nor demanded to fingerprint him as he appeared calm and readily answered questions.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL543550020080725?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=Karadzic escaped arrest in Austria last year |accessdate=26 July 2008 |publisher=Reuters |first=Boris |last=Groendahl |date=25 July 2008 }} Nevertheless, this claim came into doubt when a man named Petar Glumac, an alternative medical practitioner from [[Banatsko Novo Selo]], Serbia, claims to have been the person the police talked with in Vienna.{{cite web |url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/naslovna/aktuelno.293.html:219746-Dabic-glumio-Glumca |title=Dabić glumio Glumca |first=V. |last=Popović |website=novosti.rs |language=Bosnian |date=27 July 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2017 }} Glumac reportedly bears a striking resemblance to Karadžić's appearance as Dragan Dabić.{{cite newspaper |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/serbia/2465136/Radovan-Karadzic-stole-a-lookalikes-image.html |title=Radovan Karadzic stole a lookalike's image |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=28 July 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2017 }} Dragan Karadžić, his nephew, claimed in an interview to the ''[[Corriere della Sera]]'' that Karadžić attended football matches of [[Serie A]] and visited [[Venice]] under the name of Petar Glumac. ==Trial== {{Main|Trial of Radovan Karadžić}} ===Arrest and trial=== The arrest of Radovan Karadžić took place on 21 July 2008 in [[Belgrade]]. He was in hiding, posing as a doctor of alternative medicine mostly in [[Belgrade]] but also in [[Vienna]], Austria.{{cite news |url=http://www.wtop.com/?nid=383&sid=1444312 |title=Karadzic interviewed about details of his arrest |accessdate=26 July 2008 |agency=Associated Press}} Karadžić was transferred into ICTY custody in the [[Hague]] on 30 July.{{cite news |url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/110336/Karadzic-being-held-in-same-jail-as-Milosevic-was|title=Karadzic being held in same jail as Milosevic |publisher=gmanews.tv |accessdate=13 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522062729/http://www.gmanews.tv/story/110336/Karadzic-being-held-in-same-jail-as-Milosevic-was |archivedate=22 May 2011}} Karadžić appeared before judge [[Alphons Orie]] on 31 July, in the tribunal, which has sentenced 64 accused since 1993.{{cite web |url=http://www.icty.org/sid/24 |title=ICTY -TPIY: Key Figures |publisher=ICTY}} During the first hearing Radovan Karadžić expressed a fear for his life by saying: "If [[Richard Holbrooke|Holbrooke]] wants my death and regrets there is no death sentence at this court, I want to know if his arm is long enough to reach me here."{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/31/AR2008073100363.html?hpid=moreheadlines |title=Karadzic appears at UN court |work=Washington Post |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=20 December 2010}} and stated that the deal he made with [[Richard Holbrooke]] is the reason why it took 13 years for him to appear in front of the ICTY.{{cite web |agency=AFP |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZy0ZegDYcy8yLg1vT7wnZjJcRvw |title=Holbrooke promised no ICTY trial: Karadzic |publisher=Google |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=20 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910070936/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZy0ZegDYcy8yLg1vT7wnZjJcRvw |archivedate=10 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }} He made similar accusations against the former U.S. Secretary of State [[Madeleine Albright]].{{cite news |agency=AFP |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hDjfrs7G6ubbn16kfGGmiJuCRu0Q |title=US wants me dead: Karadžić |publisher=Google |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=20 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520153719/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hDjfrs7G6ubbn16kfGGmiJuCRu0Q |archivedate=20 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Muhamed Sacirbey]], Bosnian foreign minister at the time, claimed that a Karadžić-Holbrooke deal was made in July 1996.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=65316§ionid=351020606 |title=Karadzic-Holbrooke deal confirmed |publisher=Presstv.ir |accessdate=20 December 2010}} In August 2008 Karadžić claimed there is a conspiracy against him and refused to enter a plea, whereupon the court entered a plea of not guilty on his behalf to all 11 charges.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7587623.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Karadzic refuses war crimes pleas |date=29 August 2008 |accessdate=22 May 2010}} He called the [[tribunal]], chaired by Scottish judge [[Iain Bonomy]], a "court of NATO" disguised as a court of the international community.{{cite news |url=http://www.cctv.com/english/20080830/100530.shtml |title=UN tribunal enters plea for Karadzic |publisher=cctv.com |date=30 August 2008}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/30/world/europe/30hague.html?ref=europe |title=Karadzic Declines to Plead at War Crimes Court |work=New York Times |first=Marlise |last=Simons |date=30 August 2008}} On 13 October 2009, the BBC reported that Karadžić's plea to be granted immunity from his charges was denied. However, the start of his trial was moved to 26 October so he could prepare a defense.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8305707.stm |title=Karadzic immunity appeal rejected |publisher=BBC News |date=13 October 2009 |accessdate=13 July 2015}} On Monday 26 October 2009 Karadžić's trial was suspended after 15 minutes after he carried out his threat to boycott the start of the hearing. Judge [[O-Gon Kwon]] said that in the absence of Karadžić, who was defending himself, or any lawyer representing him, he was suspending the case for 24 hours, when the prosecution would begin its opening statement.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Watts |date=26 October 2009 |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Radovan-Karadzic-Beast-Of-Bosnia-Boycotts-Start-Of-His-Genocide-Trial-At-The-Hague/Article/200910415417404?f=rss |title='Beast Of Bosnia' Boycotts Genocide Trial |publisher=Sky News Online |accessdate=28 January 2010}} On 5 November 2009, the court imposed a lawyer on him, and postponed his trial until 1 March 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8344851.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Court imposes lawyer on Karadzic |date=5 November 2009 |accessdate=22 May 2010}} On 26 November 2009, Karadžić filed a motion challenging the legal validity and legitimacy of the tribunal, claiming that "the UN Security Council lacked the power to establish the ICTY, violated agreements under international law in so doing, and delegated non-existent legislative powers to the ICTY",{{cite web |url=http://icr.icty.org/LegalRef/CMSDocStore/Public/English/Motions/NotIndexable/IT-95-5%2318/MOT7937R0000278701.pdf |title=IT-95-5/18: Motion challenging the legal validity and legitimacy of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (English, 16 Pages) |date=20 November 2009 |format=PDF |accessdate=20 December 2010}} to which the Prosecution response was that "The Appeals Chamber has already determined the validity of the Tribunal’s creation in previous decisions which constitute established precedent on this issue", therefore dismissing the Motion.{{cite web |url=http://icr.icty.org/LegalRef/CMSDocStore/Public/English/Response/NotIndexable/IT-95-5%2318/MRA18498R0000278901.pdf |title=IT-95-5/18: Prosecution response to motion challenging the legal validity and legitimacy of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (2 Pages) |date=1 December 2009 |format=PDF |accessdate=20 December 2010}} The prosecution started its case on 13 April 2010, and completed it on 25 May 2012.{{cite web |title=Radovan Karadžić (IT-95-5/18) Case Information Sheet |url=http://www.icty.org/x/cases/karadzic/cis/en/cis_karadzic_en.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204094800/http://www.icty.org/x/cases/karadzic/cis/en/cis_karadzic_en.pdf |archivedate=4 December 2013 |deadurl=no}} The discovery of more than 300 previously unknown bodies in a mass grave at the Tomasica mine near [[Prijedor]] in September 2013 caused a flurry of motions which ended with the court denying reopening prosecutorial evidence.{{cite news |date=20 March 2014 |newspaper=Sense Agency |title=Tomasica Evidence 'Not in the Interest of Justice' |url=http://www.sense-agency.com/icty/tomasica-evidence-%E2%80%98not-in-the-interest-of-justice%E2%80%99.29.html?news_id=15799 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140401071558/http://www.sense-agency.com/icty/tomasica-evidence-%E2%80%98not-in-the-interest-of-justice%E2%80%99.29.html?news_id=15799 |archivedate=1 April 2014 |deadurl=no}} The defence began its case on 16 October 2012 and completed it in March 2014; Karadžić decided not to testify.{{cite news |title=Karadzic Decides not to Testify in His Own Defence |date=20 February 2014 |newspaper=Sense Agency |url=http://www.sense-agency.com/icty/karadzic-decides-not-to-testify-in-his-own-defense.29.html?cat_id=1&news_id=15735 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227115820/http://www.sense-agency.com/icty/karadzic-decides-not-to-testify-in-his-own-defense.29.html?cat_id=1&news_id=15735 |archivedate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=no}} Closing arguments in the case began on 29 September 2014 and were concluded on 7 October 2014,[http://www.icty.org/x/cases/karadzic/cis/en/cis_karadzic_en.pdf Case information sheet: Radovan Karadžić], [[ICTY]] Karadžić having failed in his demand for a re-trial.{{cite news |title=NO RE-MATCH IN KARADZIC CASE |date=14 August 2014 |newspaper=Sense Agency |url=http://www.sense-agency.com/icty/no-re-match-in-karadzic-case.29.html?news_id=16054 |accessdate=13 July 2015}} ===Bosnian genocide trial=== Karadžić and Mladić were placed on trial for charges of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes committed in Srebrenica, Prijedor, Ključ, and other districts of Bosnia. They were charged, separately, with:Paul R. Bartrop. (20116). ''Bosnian Genocide: The Essential Reference Guide'', p. 113. ABC-CLIO. {{ISBN|9781440838699}}. * Count 1: Genocide. On 28 June 2012, the trial chamber granted a defence motion for acquittal on this count as "the evidence, even if taken at its highest, did not reach the level from which a reasonable trier of fact could conclude that genocide occurred in the municipalities [in question]". Motions for acquittal on nine other counts were dismissed. The Appeals Chamber subsequently concluded that the court had erred and reinstated Count 1 on 11 July 2013. ** Municipalities: [[Bratunac]], [[Foča]], [[Ključ, Una-Sana Canton|Ključ]], [[Kotor Varoš]], [[Prijedor]], [[Sanski Most]], [[Vlasenica]] and [[Zvornik]]. * Count 2: Genocide. ** Municipality: [[Srebrenica]]. * Count 3: Persecutions on Political, Racial and Religious Grounds, a Crime Against Humanity. ** Municipalities: [[Banja Luka]], [[Bijeljina]], [[Bosanska Krupa]], [[Bosanski Novi]], [[Bratunac]], [[Brčko (town)|Brčko]], [[Foča]], [[Hadžići]], [[Ilidža]], [[Kalinovik]], [[Ključ, Una-Sana Canton|Ključ]], [[Kotor Varoš]], [[Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Novi Grad]], [[Novo Sarajevo]], [[Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Pale]], [[Prijedor]], [[Rogatica]], [[Sanski Most]], [[Sokolac]], [[Trnovo, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Trnovo]], [[Vlasenica]], [[Vogošća]], [[Zvornik]], and [[Srebrenica]]. * Count 4: Extermination, a Crime Against Humanity. * Count 5: Murder, a Crime Against Humanity. * Count 6: Murder, a Violation of the Laws or Customs of War. * Count 7: Deportation, a Crime Against Humanity. * Count 8: Inhumane Acts (forcible transfer), a Crime Against Humanity. * Count 9: Acts of Violence the Primary Purpose of which is to Spread Terror among the Civilian Population, a Violation of the Laws or Customs of War. * Count 10: Unlawful Attacks on Civilians, a Violation of the Laws or Customs of War. * Count 11: Taking of Hostages, a Violation of the Laws or Customs of War. The Yugoslav war crimes court rejected on 27 June 2012 one of the two genocide charges against Karadžić.{{cite web |url= http://www.icty.org/x/cases/karadzic/ind/en/markedup_indictment_091019.pdf |format= pdf |title= Prosecutor's Marked-up Indictment |id= ICTY Case No. IT-95-5/18-PT |work= The Prosecutor v Radovan Karadzic |date= 19 October 2009 |access-date= 7 June 2011 |publisher= United Nations }}{{cite web |url= http://www.icty.org/x/cases/mladic/ind/en/110601.pdf |format= pdf |title= Prosecutor's Marked-up Indictment |id= ICTY Case No. IT-09-92-I |work= The Prosecutor v Radovan Karadzic |edition= 2nd amended |date= 1 June 2011 |access-date= 7 June 2011 |publisher= United Nations }} However, on 11 July 2013, the Appeals Chamber reinstated these charges. ===Conviction and sentence=== On 24 March 2016 he was found guilty of [[genocide]], [[war crimes]] and [[crimes against humanity]], and sentenced to 40 years imprisonment.{{Cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/24/europe/karadzic-war-crimes-verdict/index.html |title=Karadzic sentenced to 40 years for genocide |website=CNN |access-date=25 March 2016}} He was found guilty of genocide for the [[Srebrenica massacre]], which aimed to kill "every able-bodied male" in the town and systematically exterminate the Bosnian Muslim community. He was also convicted of persecution, extermination, deportation, forcible transfer ([[ethnic cleansing]]), and murder in connection with his campaign to drive Bosnian Muslims and Croats out of villages claimed by Serb forces. On 27 February 2018 it was announced by the Mechanism for International Criminal Tribunals that hearings for the appeal against the conviction were set on 23 April 2018.{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/radovan-karadzic-genocide-appeal-hearings-set-for-april-02-28-2018 |title=Radovan Karadzic Genocide Appeal Hearings Set for April |website=Balkan Insight|access-date=28 February 2018}} ==Poetry== Karadžić published several books of poetry, many of which were published whilst in hiding. * 1968: ''Ludo koplje'' (Svjetlost, Sarajevo) * 1971: ''Pamtivek'' (Svjetlost, Sarajevo) * 1990: ''Crna bajka'' (Svjetlost, Sarajevo) * 1992: ''Rat u Bosni: Kako je počelo'' * 1994: ''Ima čuda, nema čuda'' * 2001: ''Od Ludog koplja do Crne bajke'' (Dobrica knjiga, Novi Sad) * 2004: ''Čudesna hronika noći'' (IGAM, Belgrade) * 2005: ''Pod levu sisu veka'' (Književna zajednica Veljko Vidaković, Niš) ==Awards and decorations== * Literary award [[Jovan Dučić]] for poetry, 1969 * Literary award [[Michail Aleksandrovich Sholokhov|Michail Sholokhov]] on 16 May 1994, by the [[Union of Russian Writers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.montenegro.org/pen.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19980702051241/http://www.montenegro.org/pen.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 July 1998|title=Montenegrin PEN Center|publisher=Montenegrin Association of America|accessdate=25 July 2008}} See also: {{cite web|url=http://www.mail-archive.com/news@antic.org/msg03067.html|title=Sholohov Prize to Milosevic|publisher=antic.org|accessdate=25 July 2008}} * Knights' Order of the First Rank of Saint Dionysius of Xanthe, 1994, by the [[Greek Orthodox Church]]. * [[Order of the Republika Srpska]], 1994 * [[Order of St. Andrew|Order of Andrew the First-Called]], 1995, by the Moscow Fund.{{cite web|url=http://www.karadzic-odbrana.com/rec-o-radovanu/744-ljiljana-bulatovic-medic-mihail-solohov-karadzicu-7.html|title=Љиљана билатовић - Медић: "Михаил Шолохов" Караџићу|author=angelina markovic|work=Радован Караџић – ОДБРАНА|accessdate=5 July 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal|Republika Srpska|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} * [[Bosnian Genocide]] * [[Serbian war crimes in the Yugoslav Wars]] {{flagicon image|Flag of the Al-Nusra Front.svg}} [[Al-Nusra Front]] |combatant2 ={{flagicon|Syria}} '''[[Syria|Ba'athist Syria]]''' *{{flagicon image|Syrian Armed Forces Flag.svg}} [[Syrian Armed Forces]] *Damascus Police {{flagicon image|PFLP-GC Flag.svg}} [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command|PFLP – GC]][http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/syria-rebels-clash-palestinians-envoy-due-china Syria rebels clash with Palestinians as envoy due in China | Egypt Independent] |commander1 = Unknown |commander2 = Brig. Gen. [[Maher al-Assad]]
Brig. Gen. [[Mohammed al-Awwad]]{{KIA}}
Brig. Gen. [[Hassan al-Ibrahim]]{{KIA}}
Brig. Gen. [[Rajeh Mahmoud]]{{KIA}} |units1 =*Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah Battalion{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/asads-armed-opposition-the-free-syrian-army|title=Asad's Armed Opposition: The Free Syrian Army|work=[[The Washington Institute for Near East Policy]]|author=Jeffrey White|date=30 November 2011}} *Muawiyah bin Abi-Sufyan Battalion |units2 ={{flagicon image|Flag of the Syrian Arab Army.svg}} 1st Army Corps: *[[3rd Armoured Division (Syria)|3rd Armoured Division]] *[[7th Infantry Division (Syria)|7th Mechanized Division]] [[File:Syrian Republican Guard SSI.svg|16px]] [[Republican Guard (Syria)|Republican Guard]]: *101 Security Regiment *102 Security Regiment |strength1 =Unknown |strength2 = 50,000 soldiers and policemen |casualties1 =at least 1,000 killed |casualties2 =at least 880 killed |casualties3 = A few hundred protesters and civilians killed{{cite web|title=Interactive: Syria death toll by location|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/interactive/2012/01/20121510467827350.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=28 September 2012}} |notes = |campaignbox ={{Campaignbox Syrian civil war}} }} {{Campaignbox Rif Dimashq Campaign}} The '''Rif Dimashq clashes''' were a series of unrests and armed clashes in and around [[Damascus]], the capital of [[Syria]], from November 2011 till a stalemate in March 2012. The violence was part of the wider [[Early insurgency phase of the Syrian Civil War|early insurgency phase]] of the [[Syrian Civil War]]. Large pro-government and anti-government protests took place in the suburbs and center of Damascus, with the situation escalating when members of the [[Free Syrian Army]] started attacking military targets in November. It is claimed that in January 2012, parts of rural Damascus and the Damascus suburbs started to fall under opposition control. On 27 January 2012, the [[Syrian Army]] launched a [[Battle of Zabadani (2012)|military operation]] which retook the Damascus suburbs and the town of [[Zabadani]] with the offensive ending on 11 February. However, fighting still continued, when on 15 February FSA fighters were seen on the streets of a district in the Damascus centre, trying to recruit and mingling with opposition protesters. A few anti-government protests were still ongoing after the army offensive. On 12 March 2012, major clashes were reported in central Damascus between the FSA and the Syrian Army for the first time. By April 2012 a fragile cease-fire was brokered by the UN peace envoy Kofi Annan. However, following the cease fire collapse, by July 2012, rebels erupted again into most Damascus suburbs and rural areas around the city, launching the [[Battle of Damascus (2012)|Battle of Damascus]], also known as Operation Damascus Volcano. == 2011 unrests and clashes == Large anti-government protests were shot at by "[[Shabiba]]", killing 23 protesters in a single day.{{cite news|last=Oweis|first=Khaled|title=32 killed in Syria protests, Damascus moves-activists|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/15/us-syria-idUSTRE76D7NP20110715|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=28 September 2012|date=15 July 2011}} More were killed in October and November.{{cite web|title=Syrian forces kill three in Damascus protest|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/syria-forces-kill-three-in-damascus-protest-1.372140|publisher=Haaretz|accessdate=28 September 2012}}{{cite web|title=Russia urges talks amid unrelenting Syria violence|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hPHSWcGclNM3GoFiJHIbjwz3BcbA?docId=CNG.e39574da76c565cc5f310844b7ae501d.941 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124230913/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hPHSWcGclNM3GoFiJHIbjwz3BcbA?docId=CNG.e39574da76c565cc5f310844b7ae501d.941 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 January 2013 |publisher=AFP|accessdate=28 September 2012}}{{cite web|title=30 protesters, 26 soldiers killed during clashes|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/45252656/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/#.TtX2nGF6DvI|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=28 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=Syria unrest: 'Arrests in Hama as tanks move on Idlib'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14011188|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=28 September 2012|date=4 July 2011}} Ten more protesters were killed around Damascus, including a 14-year-old boy.{{cite web|title=Two Syrian civilians killed in city of Homs|url=http://www.yourmiddleeast.com/news/two-syrian-civilians-killed-in-city-of-homs_3142|publisher=AFP|accessdate=28 September 2012}} Fourteen were killed in house-to-house raids and in protests in Damascus suburbs, and an activist in the eastern Damascus suburb of Harasta, who gave his name as Assem, said three deserters were killed after they abandoned military units which fired live ammunition at a demonstration of 1,500–2,000 people in the al-Zar neighbourhood. "Security police could not put down the demonstration. The eight soldiers defected when Republican Guards and the Fourth Armoured Division were sent in," he said.{{cite web|title=Video: Armed attacks in Syria growing|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/45252656/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/#.TtX2nGF6DvI|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=28 September 2012}} === November 2011 === On 16 November 2011, according to opposition sources, Syrian army deserters attacked a military intelligence office in Harasta, a suburb of the capital Damascus, killing six soldiers and wounding more than 20. "The Syrian Free Army struck with rockets and RPGs" said Omar Idlibi, the Beirut-based spokesperson for the opposition Syrian Local Co-ordination Committees. It was also said that all the army defectors involved returned after the attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/World/News/31-killed-in-Syria-as-Arab-League-meets-20111116 |title=31 killed in Syria while Arab League meets |publisher=News24.com |date=2011-11-16 |accessdate=2012-09-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldnewstribune.com/?p=1684 |title=Rebels begin military operations against Assad forces with attacks in Damascus suburbs |publisher=Worldnewstribune.com |date=2011-11-17 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119000741/http://www.worldnewstribune.com/?p=1684 |archivedate=19 November 2011 }} All other attacks targeted military checkpoints in the suburbs of Douma, Qaboun and Arabeen and [[Saqba]], killing three soldiers.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/16/syria-army-defectors-attack-base?newsfeed=true |title=Syrian army defectors attack intelligence base |publisher=Guardian |date=2011-11-16 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |location=London}}{{cite web|last=Mroue|first=Bassem|title=Syrian army defectors attack base near Damascus|url=https://news.yahoo.com/syrian-army-defectors-attack-near-damascus-071930227.html|publisher=Yahoo News|accessdate=28 September 2012}} A Russian official said that the outbreak of fighting in Damascus "looks like a civil war."{{cite web|url=http://digitaljournal.com/article/314581 |title=Fighting in Damascus 'looks like civil war' says Russian official |publisher=Digitaljournal.com |date=2011-11-17 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} On 20 November 2011, a loud explosion was reported to have occurred in the heart of Damascus, the Syrian capital, amid reports of a grenade attack on offices of the ruling Baath Party, the boldest attack by army defectors at the time.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/2011111965450949408.html |title=Arab League rejects Syrian amendments |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date=2011-11-20 |accessdate=2012-09-29}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8902190/Syrian-Baath-Party-building-hit-by-rockets.html |title=Syrian Baath Party building 'hit by rockets' |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2011-11-20|author= Josie Ensor |accessdate=2012-09-29 |location=London}} The Free Syrian Army later claimed responsibility for the attack, saying they fired two rocket-propelled grenades at the building.{{cite news|author=Luke Harding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/20/syria-rebels-baath-offices-damascus |title=Syrian rebels attack Ba'ath party offices in Damascus |publisher=Guardian |date=2011-11-20 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |location=London}} === December 2011 === In December 2011, Al Jazeera published an article; that protesters in the suburbs of Damascus did gather every evening to make their support for the Free Syrian Army known.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/12/20111226171260898.html |title=Ranks of Free Syrian Army 'gaining strength' |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date=2011-12-26 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Seeing though that this disinformation did not bring anyone on the streets, the article was later changed into.{{Clarify|reason=incoherent sentence|date=January 2014}}{{cite web|title=Ranks of Free Syrian Army 'gaining strength'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/12/20111226171260898.html|accessdate=15 January 2013}} On 4 December 2011, the SANA news agency reported that a funeral procession was held on Sunday{{When|date=January 2014}} for 13 soldiers who were killed. It claimed that killed while they were in the line of duty in Damascus countryside.{{cite web|url=http://mwcnews.net/news/middle-east/15264-violence-in-syria.html |title=Violence in Syria as sanctions deadline looms |publisher=Mwcnews.net |date=2011-12-04 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} On 9 December 2011, two children, aged 10 and 12, were among others killed by Syrian security forces on Friday in Homs and on the outskirts of Damascus, rights groups said.{{cite web|title=Syrians rally for 'dignity' amid violent crackdown|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/12/09/181677.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|accessdate=28 September 2012}} On 13 December, another person died.{{cite web|title=Russia toughens UN stance on Syria|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2011/12/20111215205512630181.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=28 September 2012}} On 23 December 2011, Syrian state TV claimed that two explosions at security bases in Damascus were caused by suicide bombers; a number of military personnel and civilians were killed.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16136114 |title=Suicide Bombers Blamed For Damascus Blasts |publisher=News.sky.com |date=2011-12-24 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417152545/http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16136114 |archivedate=17 April 2012 }} At least 44 people were reported killed and 55 others wounded.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/12/23/184128.html |title=Syria blames al-Qaeda for twin suicide attacks in Damascus; at least 44 dead |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date=2011-12-23 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} State television claimed that "several soldiers and a large number of civilians" had been killed in the bombings although an exact figure was hard to ascertain.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8974890/Syria-Up-to-40-dead-as-two-bomb-explosions-rock-Damascus.html |title=Syria: Up to 40 dead as two bomb explosions rock Damascus |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |author= Richard Spencer|date=2011-12-23|accessdate=2012-09-29 |location=London}} On 29 December 2011, Syrian security forces opened fire on tens of thousands protesting outside a mosque in a Damascus suburb called Douma, close to a municipal building that members of the Arab League monitoring mission were believed to be visiting. At least four protesters died. Rami Abdul-Rahman, head of his one-man British-based "Syrian Observatory for Human Rights", said about 20,000 people were protesting outside the Grand Mosque in Douma when troops opened fire. Cars belonging to the Arab League monitors were seen in front of a municipal building close to the mosque, he said. Abdul-Rahman and other activists said the monitors were barred by security officials from entering Douma following the killings, after the situation deteriorated.{{cite web|title=Dec 20, 2011|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-dec-29-2011-2033|work=Syria Live Blog|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=28 September 2012}} == 2012 unrests and clashes == === January 2012 === On 4 January 2012, a journalist and a host on state-owned [[Radio Damascus]] and an editor with the state-owned daily [[Al-Thawra]], was shot in the head by unidentified gunmen on Friday in his home in the Damascus suburb of Darya. State television reported that the journalist was targeted by "armed terrorist groups."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/us-jan-4-2012-0851 |title=Syria live blog Wed, 4 Jan 2012, 05:51 |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-01-04 |accessdate=2012-09-29}}{{better source|dead link|date=March 2018}} On 6 January 2012, SANA claimed that another suicide bomber killed at least 26 when a police building or intelligence building was attacked. However, the opposition pointed the finger at the Government, saying "this is a plot staged by the government to deter thousands of people that were planning to converge on that same spot to call for the international community to step in and enforce a no-fly zone and enforce also a dramatic end to the regime". Later SANA reported the death of General [[Mohammed Abdul-Hamid al-Awwad]], claiming he was assassinated while he was headed for work in the al-Ghouta area of Damascus. His driver, who was injured, said that "As we were heading to the Brigadier General's military unit, we saw a taxi on the right of the road…it overtook us and then blocked our way. Four gunmen started shooting at us. Brigadier al-Awwad was shot in the head and I was also injured."{{cite web|url=http://www.sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/16/394558.htm |accessdate=3 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120151207/http://www.sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/16/394558.htm |archivedate=20 January 2012 }} On 7 January 2012, 14 protesters were said to have died though a roadside bomb blast and anti-government protests on the same day.{{cite news|title=Syria unrest: Damascus blast and clashes kill many|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-16437865|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=28 September 2012|date=7 January 2012}} On 12 January 2012, state TV reported that an army bus was attacked in the area of the Damascus countryside with another roadside bomb and gunfire, killing four soldiers and wounding eight.{{cite web|url=http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/12/393565.htm |title=Four Army Members Martyred, Eight Injured in a Bomb Detonated by Terrorists in Ya'four Area |publisher=Sana.sy |date=2012-01-12 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201204856/http://www.sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/12/393565.htm |archivedate=1 February 2012 }} Six more soldiers (including a colonel) were killed in battles around the province, according to the Syrian government.{{cite web|title=An Officer, 2 Military Members Martyred in Damascus Countryside, Citizen Martyred in Hama |url=http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/11/393440.htm |work=Syrian Arab news agency |date=11 January 2012 |accessdate=18 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202173741/http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/11/393440.htm |archivedate=2 February 2012 }}{{cite web|work=Syrian Arab News Agency |url=http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/14/393989.htm |title=3 Military Members Martyred in Damascus Countryside, 3 Law Enforcement Members Martyred in Homs |date=14 January 2012 |accessdate=18 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129172755/http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/14/393989.htm |archivedate=29 January 2012 }} On 19 January 2012, a Syrian security officer was killed after the bombing of his car in al-Tadhamun neighborhood in Damascus.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/01/19/189256.html |title=Regime forces kill leading Syrian activists; Russia says no to Western intervention |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date=2012-01-19 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} On 22 January 2012, amidst a [[Battle of Douma|battle in the surbub of Douma]] two officers and a soldier of the Syrian Army and a deserter was killed in the Talfita area.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/01/22/189842.html |title=Saudi Arabia withdraws its monitors from Syria, urges more international pressure |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date=2012-01-22 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Rural Damascus came under rebel control. At the police hospital in Harasta, the staff said most of rural Damascus was not controlled by the government forces and gunmen were kidnapping and killing those affiliated with the government in those areas. "Any car plate that belongs to the government cannot drive inside Harasta, we as doctors cannot go, they hijacked one of our cars a week ago," said a doctor.{{cite news|last=Karouny|first=Mariam|title=Outside Syria's capital, suburbs look like war zone|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/26/us-syria-damascus-idUSTRE80P1N620120126|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=28 September 2012|date=26 January 2012}} According to the Syrian Government, Brigadier General [[Hassan Abdullah al-Ibrahim]] and a First Lieutenant were killed when their car was fired on in the Damascus countryside.{{cite web |work=Syrian Arab News Agency |url=http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/23/395797.htm |title=7 Martyred by Terrorists Gunfire in Damascus Countryside, Daraa, Homs and Hama, 2 Trucks Loaded with Weapons and Ammunition Seized in Raqqa |date=2012-01-23 |accessdate=2012-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126044608/http://sana.sy/eng/337/2012/01/23/395797.htm |archivedate=26 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ==== Syrian Army offensive ==== On 27 January 2012, the Syrian army stormed Douma.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/1121832 |title=Syrian troops storm Damascus suburb |publisher=Associated Press via Thestar.com|author=Bassem Mroue|date= 2012-01-26|accessdate=2012-09-29|location=Toronto}} On 28 January 2012, seven more soldiers died around Damascus amidst the offensive. They were ambushed.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/syria/seven-troops-killed-in-terror-attack-near-damascus-state-media-says-1.972358 |title=Seven troops killed in 'terror attack' near Damascus, state media says |publisher=Gulfnews.com |date=2012-01-28 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131212133/http://gulfnews.com/news/region/syria/seven-troops-killed-in-terror-attack-near-damascus-state-media-says-1.972358 |archivedate=31 January 2012 }} Later SANA reported that the bus was ambushed near Douma, and it was carrying army officers, in which seven of the officers died.{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jan/29/syria-6-soldiers-killed-in-bus-ambush/ |title=Syria: 6 soldiers killed in bus ambush |publisher=UTSanDiego.com |date= 2012-01-29|accessdate=2012-08-08}} On 29 January 2012, the Syrian army launched an offensive, trying to retake some of the Damascus suburbs from rebel control. Amateur video appeared to show tanks rolling in to Al-Ghouta and Zamalka to the east. Al-Ghouta is historically known for being a hub of dissent against the Assad government, and the crackdown appeared to be an attempt "to avoid any Tahrir Square-style mass movements,".{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/01/2012129131321937927.html |title=Syrian army in offensive near Damascus |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} According to activists, 14 civilians and 5 opposition fighters were killed in shelling of neighbourhoods. 2,000 pro-assad forces and 50 tanks and armoured vehicles took part in the offensive.{{cite news|last=Yacoub |first=Khaled |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/29/us-syria-idUSTRE80S08620120129 |title=Syria troops battle to retake Damascus suburbs, 19 die |publisher=Reuters.com |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} However, they met fierce resistance and six government soldiers, including two officers, were killed and six wounded in the opposition controlled suburb of Sahnaya when their bus was blown up by a remote-controlled bomb.{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jan/29/syria-6-soldiers-killed-in-bus-ambush/ |title=Syria: 6 soldiers killed in bus ambush |publisher=Utsandiego.com |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Some activists claimed that the fighting in Damascus was not unusual, and there wasn't any tanks in the city,{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-jan-29-2012-1700 |title=AJE live blog |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} while others said that it was "the worst fighting around the capital in the 10-month uprising."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-jan-29-2012-1702 |title=Syria Live Blog |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Clashes were also reported near Damascus airport, leading to its closure. "It’s urban war. There are bodies in the street," one activist, speaking from Kfar Batna told Reuters.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/01/29/191336.html |title=At least 66 killed across Syria as troops battle to retake Damascus suburbs |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Other Damascus suburbs that have come under fire from heavy artillery and mortar rounds from government forces include Douma, Saaba, [[Arbin, Syria|Arbin]] and Hamuriyeh, activists said. "The more the regime uses the army, the more soldiers defect," Ahmed al-Khatib, a local rebel council member on the Damascus outskirts, told the AFP news agency. A spokesperson for the rebel FSA, which at the time, had 40,000 men and whose leadership was in Turkey, said that the fighting came a day after "a large wave of defections," with 50 officers and soldiers turning their back on Assad.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-jan-29-2012-1817 |title=AJE live blog |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} At least two generals and other "high-ranking officers" reportedly defected to the opposition.{{cite web|author=İpek Yezdani |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/syrian-opposition-defections-rise.aspx?pageID=238&nID=12670&NewsCatID=352 |title=Syrian opposition: defections rise |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2011-09-13 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} After two days of clashes, oppositions and FSA sources confirmed that the Syrian army gained back control of some of the eastern suburbs of Damascus from the rebels and started to make house to house checks and arrests. Hamouriyeh was taken by the Syrian government, as was Kfar Batna by the end of the clashes. FSA and government forces still fought in the suburb of Saqba, according to an activist.{{cite news|last=Yacoub |first=Khaled |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/30/us-syria-idUSTRE80S08620120130 |title=Assad troops fight back against Syria rebels |publisher=Reuters.com |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-09-29}}{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16158820 |title=Syria: Violence Continues Amid Crisis Talks |publisher=News.sky.com |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201045432/http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16158820 |archivedate=1 February 2012 }}{{cite news|author=Jim Muir |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-16784711 |title=Syrian army returns to Damascus suburbs |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} However, the Free Syrian army regained control of at least one suburb, Douma, and destroyed one tank and also killing three government snipers.{{cite news|last=Malas |first=Nour |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204652904577190703938046054 |title=Syrian Uprising Intensifies As Troops Defend Capital |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Another 11 soldiers had been killed in the government offensive on the Al-Ghouta suburb, as well as six civilians.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/28149-activists-syrian-soldiers-deserters-clash-at-al-rastan |title=At Least 34 Killed in Clashes, Ambush in Syria |publisher=Naharnet.com |date=2012-01-28 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} On 30 January 2012, the fighting subsided as Syrian army extanded their control in Ghouta. The military also advanced through Saqba. An activist said that the FSA moved out of the suburbs and that the Syrian army arrested 200 opposition members in Hammourya. The death toll given by activists was 19 civilians and 6 FSA fighters, while the overall number of those killed in the previous three days, since the fighting in the area started, was 100.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/290075/20120131/syria-troops-damascus.htm |title=Syrian Troops Recapture Damascus Suburbs |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date=2012-01-31 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} After the fighting, the Free Syrian Army withdrew to unidentified positions within 10 kilometers of Damascus.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldnewstribune.com/2012/01/30/syrian-armys-counter-offensive-hit-by-casualties-defections/ |title=Syrian Army’s counter-offensive hit by casualties, defections |publisher=Worldnewstribune.com |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522081622/http://www.worldnewstribune.com/2012/01/30/syrian-armys-counter-offensive-hit-by-casualties-defections/ |archivedate=22 May 2012 }} On 31 January 2012, the Syrian army continued to advance in order to crush the last FSA pockets.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/syrian-troops-push-towards-damascus-16111322.html |title=Syrian troops push towards Damascus |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date=2012-01-31 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} The army fired into the air, as they advanced with tanks even beyond the positions from where the FSA withdrew. Activists told that the suburbs were on unannounced curfew while others were allowed to flee. The army was conducting arrests on suspected people in the district of Irbin.{{cite web|last=Dyer |first=Geoff |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e7ee0ad2-4c18-11e1-b1b5-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1l3HAhxcb |title=UN urged to endorse Syria transition plan |publisher=FT.com |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} In some instances, curfews were defied by some citizens, who put up a large opposition flag in the centre of Damascus.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-jan-31-2012-0836 |title=AJE live blog |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-01-31 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} === February 2012 === On 1 February 2012, the Syrian army extended their cleaning operations, with more troops moving into the mountainous area of Qalamoun, north of Damascus. Further north, the troops which took the control of Rankous, started to extend their control into farmland surrounding the city. In the eastern suburbs of Mesraba, activist reported that army snipers were positioned and that tanks were in the streets.{{cite news|last=Gutterman |first=Steve |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/01/us-syria-idUSTRE80S08620120201 |title=Russia says veto unacceptable Syria resolution |publisher=Reuters |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} In fighting in Wadi Barada, located north-west of Damascus in the Rif Damashk governorate, the Local Committee of Coordination initially reported that 12 people, including six FSA fighter, were killed.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/02/01/world/meast/syria-unrest/?hpt=hp_bn2 |title=U.N. Security Council at standstill on Syria, reports of deaths rise |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2012-02-01|accessdate=2012-09-29}} Four of those died during a tank bombardment by the military in an attempt to flush out the Free Syrian Army units operating in the area. A rebel spokesman put the death toll at 15.{{cite news|last=Gutterman |first=Steve |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/01/us-syria-idUSTRE80S08620120201 |title=Russia says will veto "unacceptable" Syria resolution |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 2012-02-01|accessdate=2012-09-29}} Later, the death toll of FSA fighters in the area was raised to 14 by the activist group. The opposition activist group also wrongly stated that the government poisoned the water supply of Wadi Barada, however, there was no independent confirmation and no other media reported the claim. One other FSA fighter was reportedly killed in fighting in the suburb of Moadhamieh.{{cite web |url=http://www.lccsyria.org/5962 |title=Syria Today 1-2-2012 |publisher=Lccsyria.org |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120806202953/http://www.lccsyria.org/5962 |archivedate=6 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }} The town of Deir Kanoun and Ein al Fija were also under army assaults according to the London-based SOHR.{{cite web|last=Keath |first=Lee |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/feb/1/syrian-troops-move-new-rebel-areas-near-damascus/ |title=Syrian troops move on new rebel areas near Damascus |publisher=Washingtontimes.com |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-09-29}} Syria's state news agency SANA said a general, [[Rajeh Mahmoud]], was killed along with three other soldiers on the outskirts of Damascus. In Saqba, a working-class eastern suburb city of Damascus, had in-midst a peaceful anti-government demonstrations shortly fallen into control of a dozen armed and masked fighters from the Free Syria Army (FSA).{{cite news|title=Rebel fighters control Saqba|url=http://rt.com/news/damascus-captured-masked-gunmen-877/|accessdate=15 January 2013}} FSA also tried to resist against retaking by the Syrian army, but was later purged. And the fighting had stopped after the soldiers cleared the area street by street. Checkpoints were manned at main intersections and FSA fighters had either fled or been killed or wounded in the fighting. Damages were visible in the streets. Bodies of killed civilians where found severely mutilated, some had their hands bound. A resident told that he saw tanks firing into shops and talked about Iranian and Hezbollah involvement while there was no other evidence of that. Some others vowed to continue to protest once the soldiers would have left. Another resident blamed the FSA for provoking a fight they could not win and said that ordinary people were paying the price of the fighting, fearing more fighting in the future.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/gruesome-face-of-syrias-deadly-suburban-war/story-e6frg6so-1226261250916 |title=gruesome face of Syria's deadly subur|publisher=The Times|author=Richard Beeston|date=2012-02-03 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} A Lebanese source close to the Syrian government said that the offensive had the goal to cleanse from rebels all the areas near the capital and to set up a security zone. An opposition activist named Ayman Idlibi told that the Syrian army was preparing a massive attack on the city of Zabadani, a city located north of Wadi Barada and west of Rankus.{{cite web|url=http://news.monstersandcritics.com/middleeast/news/article_1688753.php/LEAD-Syria-deploys-forces-as-1982-massacre-victims-remembered |title=LEAD: Syria deploys forces, as 1982 massacre victims remembered – Monsters and Critics |publisher=News.monstersandcritics.com |date=2012-02-02 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} On 2 February 2012, it was confirmed that the Syrian Army had retaken Douma, with its streets mostly deserted, a few days earlier. Army defectors and most families had fled into the Damascus countryside.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/russia-warns-the-un-on-syria-plan-20120201-1qtd1.html |title=Russia warns the UN on Syria plan |publisher=Theage.com.au |date=2012-02-02 |accessdate=2012-08-08 |location=Melbourne}} On 9 February 2012, seven soldiers were buried after being killed in fighting in the Damascus suburbs and other areas.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-feb-9-2012-2031 |title=Syria – Feb 9, 2012 – 20:31 – Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-02-09 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} On 10 February 2012, the FSA in a poor district of Damascus city engaged loyalist forces in a firefight. Members of the Free Syrian Army fought for four hours with armoured backed troops who entered al-Qaboun neighbourhood in the north of the capital according to witnesses, it was not immediately known how many people were killed but several FSA fighters were wounded.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-feb-10-2012-2358 |title=Syria – Feb 10, 2012 – 23:58 – Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2012-02-10 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} On 11 February 2012, more fighting was reported when SANA reported that three gunmen shot dead another army general. SANA said that General Issa al-Khouli was shot in the morning as he left his home in the Damascus neighborhood of Rukn-Eddine.
